It will not dequeue the value, meaning that it can still be read in the future by this function or the ds_queue_dequeue(). If the queue is empty then the function will return the constant undefined, otherwise it will return the real or string value contained in the queue.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to read from.

Function.Name: ds_queue_read
Function.Description: With this function you can recreate a saved DS queue (one that has previously been written as a string using ds_queue_write()). You must first create a new DS queue to read the string into, and if the DS queue already exists and has information stored in it, then this will be cleared before reading.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to read into.
The string to read from.
Can be either true or false or omitted completely.

Function.Name: ds_queue_size
Function.Description: This function will return the "size" of the queue, i.e.: the number of items that have been queued onto it.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to check.

Function.Name: ds_queue_tail
Function.Description: This function will only read the last value of the queue (that which is "at the tail"). It will not dequeue the value, meaning that it can still be read in the future by this function or by ds_queue_dequeue().
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to read from.

Function.Name: ds_queue_write
Function.Description: This function returns a string which can then be stored or transferred to another data structure using the ds_queue_read() function.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to write.

Function.Name: ds_stack_clear
Function.Description: With this function you can clear all data from the given stack data structure. This does NOT destroy the data structure (for that you should use ds_stack_destroy()) it only wipes all data from it and returns an empty stack.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to clear.

Function.Name: ds_stack_copy
Function.Description: This function can be used to copy the contents of one stack into another. Note that this does NOT remove the contents from the original stack, nor does it destroy the original stack. When using this function the stack being copied to must have been previously created and if it contained any items before the copy, then these will be cleared first (meaning this information will be lost).
Function.Parameter: The id of the NEW stack.
The ORIGINAL stack to copy to id.

Function.Name: ds_stack_create
Function.Description: This function will create a new stack data structure and return the index value. This value should be stored in a variable and used in all further function calls relating to the stack.

Function.Name: ds_stack_destroy
Function.Description: This function will remove the given stack data structure from memory, freeing up the resources it was using and removing all values that it contained. This function should always be used when you are finished using the DS stack to prevent memory leaks that can slow down and crash your game.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to remove.

Function.Name: ds_stack_empty
Function.Description: With this function you can check the given DS stack to see if it is empty (returns true) or not (returns false).
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to check.

Function.Name: ds_stack_pop
Function.Description: This function will pop the top value off of the DS stack , removing it from the stack and returning the value to be stored in a variable. If the stack is empty then the function will return the constant undefined, otherwise it will return the real or string value contained in the stack.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to pop from.

Function.Name: ds_stack_push
Function.Description: This function will push (add) a value, which can be of any data type, onto the top of the stack. The function can take a further 14 optional arguments (making a total of 15 possible additions), permitting you to push multiple values consecutively to the stack in a single call.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to push onto.
The value to push onto the stack.

Function.Name: ds_stack_read
Function.Description: With this function you can recreate a saved DS stack (one that has previously been written as a string using ds_stack_write()). You must first create a new DS stack to read the string into, and if the DS stack already exists and has information stored in it, then this will be cleared before reading.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to read into.
The string to read from.
Can be either true or false or omitted completely.

Function.Name: ds_stack_size
Function.Description: This function will return the "size" of the stack, i.e.: the number of items that have been pushed onto it.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to check.

Function.Name: ds_stack_top
Function.Description: This function will only read the first value of the stack (that which is "on top"). It will not pop the value, meaning that it can still be read in the future by this function or the ds_stack_pop(). If the stack is empty then the function will return the constant undefined, otherwise it will return the real or string value contained in the stack.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to read from.

Function.Name: ds_stack_write
Function.Description: This function returns a string which can then be stored or transferred to another data structure using the ds_stack_read() function.
Function.Parameter: The id of the data structure to write.

Function.Name: code_is_compiled
Function.Description: This function will return true if the platform compiles outside of the virtual machine, such as for the YYC and JS platforms.

Function.Name: debug_event
Function.Description: This function generates a custom debug event that will be shown in the Graph View of the debugger when a game is being run in Debug Mode. If you require messages to be displayed when not in debug mode, then you should be using show_debug_message(). It is worth noting that the function will also take two reserved strings to help perform debugging using external applications like Visual Studio.
Function.Parameter: The custom debug event string to use.
Extra configuration parameter.

Function.Name: debug_get_callstack
Function.Description: This function generates an array of strings as the "callstack" where the current script is listed first, and then all the other scripts that were run in order for the current script to be executed.
Function.Parameter: The maximum depth of the callstack

Function.Name: exception_unhandled_handler
Function.Description:
This runtime function can be used to "take over" the default GameMaker error message when a runtime exception occurs.
You supply a method or function which is called when the exception occurs, and its first argument will be a struct containing information about the exception.
Function.Parameter: The method (user-defined function) to use as the exception handler, or undefined to reset it to default.

Function.Name: get_integer
Function.Description: This function has been deprecated and is now obsolete (use get_integer_async instead). Calls to this function will produce a warning message.
Function.Parameter: The string to show in the pop-up message.
The default value in the text box.

Function.Name: get_string
Function.Description: This function has been deprecated and is now obsolete (use get_string_async instead). Calls to this function will produce a warning message.
Function.Parameter: The string to show in the pop-up message.
The default string in the text box.

Function.Name: show_debug_message
Function.Description: This function will create a custom debug message that is shown in the compiler window at runtime.
Function.Parameter: The custom debug message to show or a string format.
Values to be replaced on the format string (non-strings will be converted to strings).

Function.Name: show_debug_message_ext
Function.Description: This function will create a custom debug message that is shown in the compiler window at runtime.
Function.Parameter: The custom debug message to show.
An array of values to be replaced on the format string (non-string elements will be converted to string).

Function.Name: show_debug_overlay
Function.Description:
This function can be used to switch on and off the standard debug overlay when testing your game and is disabled by default. The debug overlay shows a graphic CPU/GPU usage bar in the actual game window itself along with the current real fps value, number of texture swaps and the number of vertex batches.
Note that texture swaps and vertex batches will never be zero and will normally show values of 2 or 3, since even with an empty room an no objects GameMaker still has to draw and batch things.
Function.Parameter: switch on (true) or off (false) the debug overlay.
if true then FPS is opened minimised (default) or false for full size
scale of the debug display. NOTE: clamped to between 0.5 and 4
alpha level of the debug windows. NOTE: clamped to between 0 and 1
enabled or disables gamepad input within the debug overlay (defaults to enabled)
index of the gamepad to restrict debug overly input to or -1 (default) for all gamepads

Function.Name: dbg_get_gamepad_input
Function.Description: Gets the status of gamepad input in the debug overlay a return of -1 indicates gamepad is disabled a return of `all` (-3) indicates gamepad input is enabled for all gamepads or any other number indicates that a specific gamepad is being used for debug overlay input

Function.Name: is_debug_overlay_open
Function.Description: Returns true if the debug overlay is open and false otherwise

Function.Name: is_mouse_over_debug_overlay
Function.Description: Returns true if the mouse is over a debug overlay window or gadget, or is being used by the debug sub-systems (i.e. for dragging)

Function.Name: is_keyboard_used_debug_overlay
Function.Description: Returns true if the keyboard is being used by the debug overlay system

Function.Name: show_debug_log
Function.Description: This function can be used to switch on and off the standard debug log and console when testing your game and is disabled by default.
Function.Parameter: switch on (true) or off (false) the debug overlay.

Function.Name: dbg_view
Function.Description: Declare a new debug view that can be accessed from the debug overlay.
Function.Parameter: name of the debug view
true if view is visible, false otherwise
x position to place the view window, -1 means position anywhere
y position to place the view window, -1 means position anywhere
width of the view window, default is 500
height of the view window, default is 400

Function.Name: dbg_section
Function.Description: Declare a new debug section this will be added to the current debug view that is active. NOTE: if no debug view is active then a "Default" view is created for you.
Function.Parameter: name of the debug section
true if section is open when created, false if closed, defaults to true

Function.Name: dbg_view_delete
Function.Description: Delete a dbg_view that has been previously been created. Returns true if section is deleted, false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: handle to the view

Function.Name: dbg_view_exists
Function.Description: Check to see if a dbg_view still exists.
Function.Parameter: handle to the view

Function.Name: dbg_section_delete
Function.Description: Delete a dbg_section that has previously been created. Returns true if section is deleted, false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: handle to the section

Function.Name: dbg_control_delete
Function.Description: Delete a dbg_* control (slider, button, checkbox etc.) that has previously been created. Returns true if control is deleted, false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: handle to the control

Function.Name: dbg_control_exists
Function.Description: Checks if a dbg_* control (slider, button, checkbox etc.) exists. Returns true if control exists, false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: handle to the control

Function.Name: dbg_set_section
Function.Description: Sets the current active section to be the one given, any new controls will be added to this section.
Function.Parameter: handle to the section

Function.Name: dbg_set_view
Function.Description: Sets the current active view to be the one given, any new controls will be added to this view and the active section within that view.
Function.Parameter: handle to the view

Function.Name: dbg_section_exists
Function.Description: Check to see if a dbg_section still exists
Function.Parameter: handle to the section

Function.Name: dbg_slider
Function.Description: Creates a slider for a real value within the current debug section, minimum and maximum values can be specified. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable to change or array of references to variables
minimum value
maximum value
label to use.
step value (numbers <=0 indicate no step).

Function.Name: dbg_slider_int
Function.Description: Creates a slider for an integer value within the current debug section, minimum and maximum values can be specified. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable to change or array of references to variables
minimum value
maximum value
label to use.
step value (numbers <=0 indicate no step).

Function.Name: dbg_add_font_glyphs
Function.Description:
Adds a TTF font to be used in the debug rendering. The font should be added to the included files, the size of the font can be specified in pixels, and a font range can be selected (glyphs must be present in the given TTF font):
* -1 - Default Latin range
* 0 - Greek
* 1 - Korean
* 2 - Japanese
* 3 - Chinese Full
* 4 - Chinese Simplified Common
* 5 - Cyrillic
* 6 - Thai
* 7 - Vietnamese
Function.Parameter: filename of a TTF file to use
size of the font in pixels(default is 13)
fontRange type (default is -1 - Latin range)

Function.Name: dbg_drop_down
Function.Description: Creates a drop down for a value within the current debug section, Either use an array of values (with an optional array of labels for those names) OR the values and names are declared as a comma delimited string - where integer values can be specified after a colon symbol so "Zero,One:10,Two:20" will create a 3 entry drop down that will set the variable to the value 0, 10 or 20 depending on which is selected. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable to change or array of references to variables
dropdown specifier or array of values
label to use or array of Labels (previous argument needs to be an array)
label to use.

Function.Name: dbg_watch
Function.Description: Creates a watch for any value within the current debug section, each value is converted to a string and displayed. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable to change or array of references to variables
label to use.

Function.Name: dbg_text
Function.Description: Creates a text entry (from a variable) within the current debug section, this text can be multiline and is not split into 2 columns but shown in a single column. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable to change or array of references to variables, or a string to show

Function.Name: dbg_text_separator
Function.Description: Creates a text separator entry (from a variable) within the current debug section, this text can be multiline and is not split into 2 columns but shown in a single column. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable to change or array of references to variables or a string to show
alignment of the text separator (0=left, 1=centre, 2=right) defaults to left alignment

Function.Name: dbg_sprite
Function.Description: Creates a sprite view of the specified sprite with the specified index within the current debug section. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable for the sprite index or array of references to variables
reference to the variable for the image index or array of references to variables
label to use.
width to draw the sprite at, if no height given then maintains the correct ratio for the sprite, default is width of the sprite
height draw the sprite at, default is height of the sprite (or uses a given width to maintain correct ratio of width to height)

Function.Name: dbg_text_input
Function.Description: Creates a text input entry within the current debug section. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable to change or array of references to variables
label to use.
type to store value as, default is string, use "s" or "t" for string, use "i" or "d" for integer, use "f", "r" or "g" for real

Function.Name: dbg_checkbox
Function.Description: Creates a check box entry within the current debug section, variable will be a boolean value true or false. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable to change or array of references to variables
label to use.

Function.Name: dbg_colour
Function.Description: Creates a colour entry within the current debug section, variable will be a colour RGB value, no alpha. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable to change or array of references to variables
label to use.

Function.Name: dbg_color
Function.Description: Creates a color entry within the current debug section, variable will be a color RGB value, no alpha. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the variable to change or array of references to variables
label to use.

Function.Name: dbg_button
Function.Description: Creates a button within the current debug section, the given method will be called when the button is pressed; it is not split into 2 columns but shown in a single column. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: label to use.
reference to the function to call
width of button in pixels.
height of button in pixels.

Function.Name: dbg_sprite_button
Function.Description: Creates a button within the current debug section, the given method will be called when the button is pressed; it is not split into 2 columns but shown in a single column. The sprite is specified with the given reference, the width and height of the button specified in pixels (width and height of the sprite is used if not specified). Bits of the sprite can be displayed by specifying the x and y offset along with width and height (if none given then the whole sprite is used). NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.
Function.Parameter: reference to the function to call
reference to the variable for the sprite index or array of references to variables
reference to the variable for the image index or array of references to variables
width of button in pixels.
height of button in pixels.
xoffset into the sprite in pixels.
yoffset into the sprite in pixels.
width of the sprite in pixels.
height of the sprite in pixels.

Function.Name: dbg_same_line
Function.Description: Causes the next debug control to be placed on the same line as the current debug control (if they are single column controls)

Function.Name: ref_create
Function.Description: Create a debug reference to a live variable
Function.Parameter: reference to the thing to derefernce
reference to the index variable or the name of the variable to dereference.
Index value to use for array references.

Function.Name: show_error
Function.Description: This function will show a custom string as an error message. You can also specify whether the game should be aborted after the error, however please note that this only exists for compatibility reasons and showing errors will require the game to be aborted regardless of the value specified in this argument.
Function.Parameter: The string to show in the pop-up message.
Whether to abort (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: show_message
Function.Description: This function creates a pop-up message box which displays the given string and a button marked "Ok" to close it.
Function.Parameter: The string to show in the pop-up message.

Function.Name: show_question
Function.Description: This function creates a pop-up message box with two buttons for "Yes" and "No". It returns true or false depending on which one of the two buttons the user presses.
Function.Parameter: The string to show in the pop-up question.

Function.Name: draw_enable_drawevent
Function.Description: With this function you can choose to enable (true) or disable (false) the draw event for all instances in the game, thus giving you control over how and when things are drawn. This can be, for example, useful if you wish to implement a "frame skip" technique.
Function.Parameter: Set to true or false.

Function.Name: draw_flush
Function.Description: This function flushes the entire draw pipeline.

Function.Name: draw_arrow
Function.Description: This function will draw an arrow from point (x1, y1) to point (x2, y2). The stem of the arrow is drawn along these points with the actual arrow head being drawn at the end, where the size of the arrowhead is defined by the argument "size" and is calculated as being part of the stem so that the end point is always aligned with the position defined by (x2, y2). The width of the arrow head is calculated automatically in proportion to the length.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line (where the arrowhead ends).
The y coordinate of the end of the line (where the arrowhead ends).
The length of the arrow in pixels.

Function.Name: draw_button
Function.Description: This function will draw a very simple, rectangular "button" using the currently selected draw colour and alpha where the up argument defines how the beveled edge effect looks.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the button
The y coordinate of the top of the button
The x coordinate of the right of the button
The y coordinate of the bottom of the button
Whether the button is up (true) or down (false)

Function.Name: draw_circle
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a circle or a filled circle. You can define how precise the drawing is with the function draw_set_circle_precision().
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.
The y coordinate of the center of the circle.
The circle's radius (length from its center to its edge)
Whether the circle is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

Function.Name: draw_circle_colour
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a circle or a filled circle, and if it is filled you can define the interior and exterior fill colours.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.
The y coordinate of the center of the circle.
The radius (distance from center to edge) of the circle in pixels.
The colour at the center of the circle.
The colour at the edge of the circle.
Whether the circle is an outline (true) or not (false). If true, col1 is irrelevant.

Function.Name: draw_ellipse
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of an ellipse or a filled ellipse by defining a rectangular area that will then have the ellipse created to fit.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the ellipse.
The y coordinate of the top of the ellipse.
The x coordinate of the right of the ellipse.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the ellipse.
Whether the ellipse is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

Function.Name: draw_ellipse_colour
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of an ellipse or a filled ellipse by defining a rectangular area that will then have the ellipse created to fit.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the ellipse.
The y coordinate of the top of the ellipse.
The x coordinate of the right of the ellipse.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the ellipse.
The colour of the center.
The colour of the edge.
Whether the ellipse is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_healthbar
Function.Description: With this function you can draw a coloured bar to show a constant value. Although the function uses the word "healthbar" you can use this to display anything you wish as long as the amount to be displayed is a percentage value between 0 and 100 (a percentage of any value can be calculated with the formula (CURRENT_Value / MAXIMUM_value) * 100).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the healthbar
The y coordinate of the top of the healthbar
The x coordinate of the right of the healthbar
The y coordinate of the bottom of the healthbar
The variable which defines total health (between 0 and 100)
The colour of the background for the bar
The colour of the bar when at no health (0)
The colour of the bar when at full health (100)
Where the bar is "anchored" (0 = left, 1 = right, 2 = top, 3 = bottom)
Whether the bar's background is drawn (true) or not (false). If false, the backcol argument is disregarded.
Whether the bar's elements have a 1px wide black border (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: draw_line
Function.Description: With this function you can draw a 1 pixel wide line between any two points in the game room. Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line.
The y coordinate of the end of the line.

Function.Name: draw_line_colour
Function.Description: With this function you can draw a 1 pixel wide line with the colour blended between colour 1 at the first point and colour 2 at the second point. The colour settings will override the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line.
The y coordinate of the end of the line.
The colour of the start of the line.
The colour of the end of the line.

Function.Name: draw_line_width
Function.Description: With this function you can draw a line of a specified width between any two points in the game room. Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line.
The y coordinate of the end of the line.
The width of the line in pixels.

Function.Name: draw_line_width_colour
Function.Description: With this function you can draw a line of a specific width with the colour blended between colour 1 at the first point and colour 2 at the second point. The colour settings will override the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line.
The y coordinate of the end of the line.
The width in pixels of the line.
The colour of the start of the line.
The colour of the end of the line.

Function.Name: draw_path
Function.Description: With this function you can get GameMaker to draw a path to the screen. The path will be drawn as a simple line, and can be either relative to the calling instance or at the absolute position it was created at in the path editor or through code.
Function.Parameter: The path to draw
The x coordinate of where the path is drawn
The y coordinate of where the path is drawn
Whether the path is drawn at the absolute position (true) or the relative position (false)

Function.Name: draw_point
Function.Description: With this function you can draw a single pixel anywhere on the screen, using the currently set draw colour and alpha.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the point to be drawn.
The y coordinate of the point to be drawn.

Function.Name: draw_point_colour
Function.Description: With this function you can draw a single pixel anywhere on the screen with a colour that you define. The colour settings will override the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour().
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the point.
The y coordinate of the point.
The colour of the point.

Function.Name: draw_rectangle
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rectangle or a filled rectangle where the (x1, y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2, y2) position is the bottom right corner. Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the top left corner of the rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top left corner of the rectangle.
The x coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rectangle.
Whether the rectangle is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

Function.Name: draw_rectangle_colour
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rectangle or a filled rectangle by defining an area where the (x1, y1) position is the top-left corner and the (x2, y2) position is the bottom-right corner. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for each corner point and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will override the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top of the rectangle.
The x coordinate of the right of the rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the rectangle.
The colour of the top left corner.
The colour of the top right corner.
The colour of the bottom right corner.
The colour of the bottom left corner.
Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_roundrect
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1, y1) position is the top-left corner and the (x2, y2) position is the bottom-right corner. You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(), but this function uses a fixed radius for them (should you need to change the corner radius, use the function draw_roundrect_ext()). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the top left corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).
The y coordinate of the top left corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).
The x coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).
The y coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).
Whether the rounded rectangle is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

Function.Name: draw_roundrect_colour
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1, y1) position is the top-left corner and the (x2, y2) position is the bottom-right corner. If it is filled, you can define the individual colours for the centre and the edges, and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will override the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()).You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(), but the corners are always drawn with a fixed radius. Should you need to change the corner radius you should use the function draw_roundrect_colour_ext(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the rounded rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top of the rounded rectangle.
The x coordinate of the right of the rounded rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the rounded rectangle.
The center colour.
The outside edge colour.
Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_roundrect_colour_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1, y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2, y2) position is the bottom right corner. If the rectangle is filled, then the colour arguments will be used to generate a colour gradient from the centre to the edges, where colour 1 is the centre colour and colour 2 the edge colour. You must also supply radius values for the x and y axis (in pixels) and the corners will be rounded by these amounts. You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the rounded rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top of the rounded rectangle.
The x coordinate of the right of the rounded rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the rounded rectangle.
The radius of the curve along the x axis from the rectangle corners.
The radius of the curve along the y axis from the rectangle corners.
The center colour.
The outside edge colour.
Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_roundrect_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1, y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2, y2) position is the bottom right corner. You must also supply radius values for the x and y axis (in pixels) and the corners will be rounded by these amounts. You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the top left corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).
The y coordinate of the top left corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).
The x coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).
The y coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).
The radius of the curve along the x axis from the rectangle corners.
The radius of the curve along the y axis from the rectangle corners.
Whether the rounded rectangle is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

Function.Name: draw_set_circle_precision
Function.Description: This function sets the precision GameMaker uses when drawing circles.
Function.Parameter: The precision of all circles drawn after this function is called. Can be between 4 and 64 and must be divisible by 4. Default is 24.

Function.Name: draw_get_circle_precision
Function.Description: This function gets the precision GameMaker uses when drawing circles.

Function.Name: draw_triangle
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a triangle or a filled triangle.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the triangle's first corner.
The y coordinate of the triangle's first corner.
The x coordinate of the triangle's second corner.
The y coordinate of the triangle's second corner.
The x coordinate of the triangle's third corner.
The y coordinate of the triangle's third corner.
Whether the triangle is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

Function.Name: draw_triangle_colour
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a triangle or a filled triangle. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for each corner point and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will override the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the triangle's first corner.
The y coordinate of the triangle's first corner.
The x coordinate of the triangle's second corner.
The y coordinate of the triangle's second corner.
The x coordinate of the triangle's third corner.
The y coordinate of the triangle's third corner.
The colour of the first corner.
The colour of the second corner.
The colour of the third corner.
Whether the triangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: colour_get_blue
Function.Description: This function returns the amount of blue used to make the given colour, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no blue and 255 is all blue.
Function.Parameter: The colour to check

Function.Name: colour_get_green
Function.Description: This function returns the amount of green used to make the given colour, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no green and 255 is all green.
Function.Parameter: The colour to check

Function.Name: colour_get_hue
Function.Description: This function will return the hue of the given colour. This is the "pure" colour tone which is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a colour.
Function.Parameter: The colour to check

Function.Name: colour_get_red
Function.Description: This function returns the amount of red used to make the given colour, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no red and 255 is all red.
Function.Parameter: The colour to check

Function.Name: colour_get_saturation
Function.Description: This function will return the saturation of the given colour. This is the amount of the colour tone that is mixed into the final colour and is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a colour.
Function.Parameter: The colour to check

Function.Name: colour_get_value
Function.Description: This function will return the value (luminosity) of the given colour. This is the amount of the "light" that is mixed into the final colour and is part of the hue, saturation and value method for defining a colour.
Function.Parameter: The colour to check

Function.Name: draw_clear
Function.Description: This function can be used to clear the entire screen (with no alpha blend) to the given colour, and is only for use in the draw event of an instance (it will not show if used in any other event). It can also be useful for clearing surfaces when they are newly created.
Function.Parameter: The colour with which the screen will be cleared

Function.Name: draw_clear_alpha
Function.Description: This function can be used to clear the entire screen or a surface with the given colour and the alpha component of the destination is set to the value you have set.
Function.Parameter: The colour with which the screen will be cleared
The transparency of the colour with which the screen will be cleared

Function.Name: draw_clear_depth
Function.Description: This function can be used to clear the depth buffer of the current render target.
Function.Parameter: The value to clear the depth buffer with.

Function.Name: draw_clear_ext
Function.Description: This function can be used to clear colour, depth and stencil of the current render target.
Function.Parameter: The colour to clear the current render target with. If undefined, then colour is not cleared. Must be specified if the argument alpha is not undefined.
The alpha value to clear the current render target with. If undefined, then colour is not cleared. Must be specified if the argument col is not undefined.
The value to clear the depth buffer with. If undefined, then depth is not cleared.
The value to clear the stencil buffer with. If undeifned, then stencil is not cleared.

Function.Name: draw_clear_stencil
Function.Description: This function can be used to clear the stencil buffer of the current render target.
Function.Parameter: The value to clear the stencil buffer with.

Function.Name: draw_getpixel
Function.Description: With this function you can get the colour value of any pixel that is being drawn to the current render target. This means that the results will depend on the event in which the function is called, and also on the target surface being used. Note that this will not return any alpha values, for that you should use draw_getpixel_ext().
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the pixel to check
The y coordinate of the pixel to check

Function.Name: draw_getpixel_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can get the full abgr 32bit value of any pixel that is being drawn to the current render target. This means that the results will depend on the event in which the function is called, and also on the target surface being used.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the pixel to check
The y coordinate of the pixel to check

Function.Name: draw_get_alpha
Function.Description: This function returns the current value of the draw alpha, which will range between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 (fully opaque). The draw alpha affects the transparency of all draw functions, and can be set with the draw_set_alpha() function.

Function.Name: draw_get_colour
Function.Description: This function returns the current draw colour which is used for drawing forms, text, primitives and untextured 3D models. This can be set with the draw_set_colour() function.

Function.Name: draw_set_alpha
Function.Description: With this function you can set the base draw alpha for the game. This value can be set from 0 to 1 with 0 being fully transparent and 1 being fully opaque (the default value), and will affect all further drawing, including backgrounds, sprites, fonts, primitives and 3D.
Function.Parameter: The alpha to set (between 0 and 1)

Function.Name: draw_set_colour
Function.Description: With this function you can set the base draw colour for the game. This value will affect all further drawing where appropriate, including fonts, forms, primitives and 3D. If any of those assets are drawn with their own colour value changed, this value will be ignored.
Function.Parameter: The colour to set for drawing.

Function.Name: make_colour_hsv
Function.Description: This function creates a colour based on the hue, saturation and value components.
Function.Parameter: The hue of the colour
How saturated the colour is
How dark the colour is

Function.Name: make_colour_rgb
Function.Description: This function creates a colour based on the red, green and blue components.
Function.Parameter: The red component of the colour
The green component of the colour
The blue component of the colour

Function.Name: merge_colour
Function.Description: With this function you can take two colours and then merge them together to make a new colour. The amount of each of the component colours can be defined by changing the "amount" argument, where a value of 0 will return the first colour (col1), a value of 1 will return the second colour (col2) and a value in between will return the corresponding mix. For example, a value of 0.5 will mix the two colours equally.
Function.Parameter: The first colour to merge
The second colour to merge
How much of each colour should be merged. For example, 0 will return col1, 1 will return col2, and 0.5 would return a merge of both colours equally

Function.Name: gpu_get_sprite_cull
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see whether sprite culling is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false).

Function.Name: gpu_get_alphatestenable
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see whether alpha testing is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false).

Function.Name: gpu_get_alphatestref
Function.Description: You can use this function to find the current value for the alpha test reference (default is 0, but you can use gpu_set_alphatestref() to set this value to something other than this).

Function.Name: gpu_get_blendenable
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the alpha blending state. If it returns true then alpha blending is enabled, and if it returns false it is disabled. By default this is on and so the function will return true.

Function.Name: gpu_get_blendmode
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current blend mode being used for drawing.

Function.Name: gpu_get_blendmode_dest
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current destination extended blend mode factor being used for drawing.

Function.Name: gpu_get_blendmode_destalpha
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current destination extended blend mode alpha factor.

Function.Name: gpu_get_blendmode_ext
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current extended blend mode being used for drawing.

Function.Name: gpu_get_blendmode_ext_sepalpha
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current extended blend mode being used for drawing, separating out the blend modes into two parts - the RGB component and the alpha component.

Function.Name: gpu_get_blendmode_src
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current source extended blend mode factor being used for drawing.

Function.Name: gpu_get_blendmode_srcalpha
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current source extended blend mode alpha factor.

Function.Name: gpu_get_blendequation
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current blend equation being used for drawing.

Function.Name: gpu_get_blendequation_sepalpha
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current blend and alpha blend equations being used for drawing.

Function.Name: gpu_get_colourwriteenable
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current colour write-enable values.

Function.Name: gpu_get_cullmode
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the backface culling mode.

Function.Name: gpu_get_fog
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the fog settings.

Function.Name: gpu_get_state
Function.Description: This function will get the current GPU state, returning it as a DS Map. This can then be manipulated or even saved, and you can return this map to the GPU using the function gpu_set_state().

Function.Name: gpu_get_stencil_depth_fail
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the stencil operation executed when the stencil test passes but the depth test fails.

Function.Name: gpu_get_stencil_enable
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve whether the stencil test is currently enabled (returns true) or not (returns false).

Function.Name: gpu_get_stencil_fail
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the stencil operation executed when the stencil test fails.

Function.Name: gpu_get_stencil_func
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current stencil test function.

Function.Name: gpu_get_stencil_pass
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the stencil operation executed when both stencil and depth test pass.

Function.Name: gpu_get_stencil_read_mask
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current stencil test read mask value.

Function.Name: gpu_get_stencil_ref
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current stencil test reference value.

Function.Name: gpu_get_stencil_write_mask
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current stencil test write mask value.

Function.Name: gpu_get_texfilter
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see whether texture filtering (linear interpolation) is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false).

Function.Name: gpu_get_texfilter_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see whether texture interpolation (linear interpolation) is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false) for a given shader sampler texture.
Function.Parameter: The sampler id from the shader.

Function.Name: gpu_get_texrepeat
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see whether texture repeating is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false).

Function.Name: gpu_get_texrepeat_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see whether texture repeating is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false) for a given shader sampler texture.
Function.Parameter: The sampler id from the shader.

Function.Name: gpu_get_zfunc
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the z comparison mode.

Function.Name: gpu_get_ztestenable
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve whether z-testing is enabled (the function returns true) or not (the function returns false). The default value is that z-testing is disabled, so the function will return false.

Function.Name: gpu_get_depth
Function.Description: This function returns the current depth (z coordinate) for 2D drawing functions. By default, it will be equal to the current layer's depth, but can be changed using gpu_set_depth.

Function.Name: gpu_get_zwriteenable
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve whether z-writing is enabled (the function returns true) or not (the function returns false). The default value is that z-writing is enabled, so the function will return true.

Function.Name: gpu_pop_state
Function.Description: This function pops the previous GPU state from the stack and applies it. See gpu_push_state() for more information.

Function.Name: gpu_push_state
Function.Description: With this function you can push the current GPU state onto a stack to be used later. You would generally use this if you want to "save" the current GPU state (things like blend mode, alpha writing, culling, etc., will all be pushed to the stack), then draw something with different settings, and then reset the GPU stack to what it was before (by calling gpu_pop_state()).

Function.Name: gpu_set_sprite_cull
Function.Description: This function will enable or disable sprite culling for your game (by default this is enabled). By switching sprite culling off you can avoid any problems with for example sprites not being drawn when using custom shaders that alter the position the sprite is drawn at.
Function.Parameter: Enable or disable sprite culling (true / false)

Function.Name: gpu_set_alphatestenable
Function.Description: This function will enable or disable alpha testing for your game (by default this is disabled). By switching alpha testing on you can then use the companion function gpu_set_alphatestref() to set the "cut-off" value at which all alpha values will be set to 0.
Function.Parameter: Enable or disable alpha testing (true / false)

Function.Name: gpu_set_alphatestref
Function.Description: This function will set the reference value for the alpha testing (when it has been enabled using the gpu_set_alphatestenable()). This is the "cut-off" threshold at which pixels with alpha will not be drawn.
Function.Parameter: Sets the reference value for alpha testing from 0 to 255 (default value is 0)

Function.Name: gpu_set_blendenable
Function.Description: This function can be used to toggle alpha blending on and off.
Function.Parameter: Enable or disable alpha blending value (true or false).

Function.Name: gpu_set_blendmode
Function.Description: This function permits you to set the blend mode to one of the basic blend modes in GameMaker.
Function.Parameter: The blend mode to use

Function.Name: gpu_set_blendmode_ext
Function.Description: This function permits you to create a custom blend mode by setting the different component parts that should be factored together.
Function.Parameter: Source blend mode factor.
Destination blend mode factor

Function.Name: gpu_set_blendmode_ext_sepalpha
Function.Description: This function permits you to set the different component parts that should be factored together to create a custom blend mode, selecting different blend mode factors for the RGB components and the alpha component.
Function.Parameter: Source blend mode factor for RGB.
Destination blend mode factor for RGB.
Source blend mode factor Alpha.
Destination blend mode factor Alpha.

Function.Name: gpu_set_blendequation
Function.Description: With this function you can change how the final pixel is calculated from the source and destination.
Function.Parameter: The blend equation to use

Function.Name: gpu_set_blendequation_sepalpha
Function.Description: This function is the same as gpu_set_blendequation(), however it allows you to set two separate equations: the first one is used for the RGB components of the source and destination, and the second one is used for the alpha component.
Function.Parameter: The blend equation to use
The alpha blend equation to use

Function.Name: gpu_set_colourwriteenable
Function.Description: With this function you can switch on or off the colour channels and the alpha channel for all further drawing.
Function.Parameter: Enable/disable the red channel
Enable/disable the green channel
Enable/disable the blue channel
Enable/disable the alpha channel

Function.Name: gpu_set_cullmode
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the backface culling mode.
Function.Parameter: The cull mode to use

Function.Name: gpu_set_fog
Function.Description: This function can be used to enable or disable fog drawing.
Function.Parameter: Enable or disable fog
The fog colour
The distance to start applying fog from
The distance to end the fog

Function.Name: gpu_set_scissor
Function.Description: This function can be used to set a scissor region that will clip all rendering to the current render target, all coordinates are in render target coordinate system. NOTE: All values are used as integers. NOTE: Each surface and viewport will reset the current scissor region (they are not stacked).
Function.Parameter: x coord OR a struct that contains {x, y, w, h}
y coord
width in render target pixels
height in render target pixels

Function.Name: gpu_get_scissor
Function.Description: This function can be used to get the current scissor region, returns a struct that contains {x, y, w, h}.

Function.Name: gpu_set_state
Function.Description: This function will set the current GPU state using the passed-in DS Map.
Function.Parameter: The GPU state to set as a DS Map.

Function.Name: gpu_set_stencil_depth_fail
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the stencil operation taken when the stencil test passes but the depth test fails.
Function.Parameter: The operation executed when the stencil test passes but the depth test fails.

Function.Name: gpu_set_stencil_enable
Function.Description: This function can be used to disable or enable the stencil test.
Function.Parameter: Enable or disable the stencil test (true or false).

Function.Name: gpu_set_stencil_fail
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the stencil operation taken when the stencil test fails.
Function.Parameter: The operation executed when the stencil test fails.

Function.Name: gpu_set_stencil_func
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the stencil test function.
Function.Parameter: The stencil test function.

Function.Name: gpu_set_stencil_pass
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the stencil operation taken when both the stencil and the depth test pass.
Function.Parameter: The operation executed when both stencil and depth test pass.

Function.Name: gpu_set_stencil_read_mask
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the stencil test read mask.
Function.Parameter: A mask that enables or disables reading of individual bits during stencil test.

Function.Name: gpu_set_stencil_ref
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the stencil test reference value.
Function.Parameter: The stencil test reference value in range 0 to 255 (inclusive).

Function.Name: gpu_set_stencil_write_mask
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the stencil test write mask.
Function.Parameter: A mask that enables or disables writing of individual bits during stencil test

Function.Name: gpu_set_texfilter
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the texture filtering (linear interpolation) of all images drawn on the game screen. When enabled (true) all textures (includes sprites) will be smoothed when drawn, meaning that when scaled or moved if there is not a 1:1 pixel ratio then there will be a "smudging" across various pixels which may make images appear blurry. If this is disabled (false) then images will be drawn based on the nearest pixel when scaled or moving which may lead to "blocky" images.
Function.Parameter: Whether to enable or disable texture filtering (default is false, or the value set in the Game Options)

Function.Name: gpu_set_texfilter_ext
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the linear interpolation for a single sampler "slot" when using Shaders in GameMaker. When this is enabled (true) the sampler texture will be smoothed and if this is disabled (false) then images will be drawn based on the nearest pixel. The default value is that set by the Global Game Options for your game, or that set using the function gpu_set_texfilter().
Function.Parameter: The sampler id from the shader.
Enable or disable texture filtering (true / false)

Function.Name: gpu_set_texrepeat
Function.Description: This function can be used to indicate to GameMaker whether textures should repeat (true) or not (false) when used with models and primitives. When enabled the GPU will treat UV coordinates outside of the 0 to 1 range as inside this range (e.g. 1.2, 2.2, 3.2, etc., all become 0.2) which causes texture images to repeat, instead of clamping them between 0 and 1 (no repetition).
Function.Parameter: Enable or disable texture filtering (true / false)

Function.Name: gpu_set_texrepeat_ext
Function.Description: This function can be used to set whether a single sampler "slot" repeats the given texture when using Shaders in GameMaker. Setting it to true will repeat the texture if the uv coordinates are outside of the 0-1 range, while a setting of false will mean no repeating. Note that for this to work on a single sprite the sprite will need to be marked as being on a "Separate Texture Page" in the Sprite Editor.
Function.Parameter: The sampler id from the shader.
Enable or disable texture filtering (true / false)

Function.Name: gpu_set_zfunc
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the z-buffer testing comparison mode (see gpu_set_ztestenable() for more information).
Function.Parameter: The comparison mode to use

Function.Name: gpu_set_ztestenable
Function.Description:
This function can be used to toggle z-buffer testing on or off. When enabled the GPU tests on a per-pixel basis if the source pixel is closer than the destination pixel, which determines whether it is drawn.
Note that the default comparison checks if the z value of a pixel is less or equal (cmpfunc_lessequal) than that of the pixel drawn to, but this can be changed using function gpu_set_zfunc().
Function.Parameter: Enable or disable z-buffer testing (true or false).

Function.Name: gpu_set_depth
Function.Description:
This function can be used to change the depth (z coordinate) for 2D drawing functions. By default, the layer's depth will be used.
Note that GameMaker will only change the depth when it starts drawing a new layer, so you may want to restore the original value (from gpu_get_depth()) after you're done drawing.
Function.Parameter: New drawing depth.

Function.Name: gpu_set_zwriteenable
Function.Description: This function can be used to toggle on (true) and off (false) depth ordering using the z-buffer.
Function.Parameter: The comparison mode to use

Function.Name: draw_get_lighting
Function.Description: This function will return whether lighting is enabled (true) or not (false) for the whole scene.

Function.Name: draw_light_define_ambient
Function.Description: This function is used to control the ambient light of a scene, which is the light that you have in a scene even without having defined any point or directional light sources.
Function.Parameter: The colour to use (either a constant, a real or a hex value).

Function.Name: draw_light_define_direction
Function.Description: This function is for defining a directional light, where the direction and intensity are set by the values input for the x, y and z unit vector (meaning that they must be between -1 and 1, where 1 or -1 is full intensity, and 0 is no intensity).
Function.Parameter: The index number of the light (arbitrary)
The x component of the light vector
The y component of the light vector
The z component of the light vector
The colour to use for the light (either a constant, a real or a hex value).

Function.Name: draw_light_define_point
Function.Description: This function is for defining a positional light, where you can define the x, y and z position of the light, the light range and its colour (which will also affect the perceived intensity of the light as certain colours appear "darker" than others).
Function.Parameter: The index number of the light (arbitrary)
The x position of the light
The y position of the light
The z position of the light
The light range (in pixels)
The colour to use for the light (either a constant, a real or a hex value).

Function.Name: draw_light_enable
Function.Description: This function is used to enable a defined light. When you define a positional or a directional light you must assign it an index number which is then used by this function to switch the light on or off. Default is disabled (false).
Function.Parameter: The index number of the light (from 0 to 7)
Enable or disable all lighting (true or false)

Function.Name: draw_light_get
Function.Description:
This function will get the specified light parameters as an array with the following 6 elements:
* [0] = enabled / disabled (true / false) * [1] = Light Type Constant * [2] = x position * [3] = y position * [4] = z position * [5] = light radius (only for point lights, will be 0 for directional) * [6] = light colour (a real)
Function.Parameter: The index number of the light (from 0 to 7)

Function.Name: draw_light_get_ambient
Function.Description: This function will return the current colour used for ambient lighting.

Function.Name: draw_set_lighting
Function.Description: This function is used to enable all lighting effects. Default is disabled (false).
Function.Parameter: enable or disable all lighting (true or false)

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_max_aniso
Function.Description: With this function you can get the current maximum level of anisotropy when using the tf_anisotropic filter mode. The returned value will range between 1 and 16.

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_max_aniso_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can get the current maximum level of anisotropy when using the tf_anisotropic filter mode on a shader sampler.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_max_mip
Function.Description: With this function you can get the currently set maximum mipmap level which is to be used, where a value of 0 is the highest resolution, 1 is to use the first mipmap, 2 is the second, etc.

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_max_mip_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can get the currently set maximum mipmap level which is to be used for a given shader sampler. Note that this can be quite useful for avoiding bleeding artifacts when rendering textures, for example, setting the texture page border to 8px and then setting the max mipmap level to 3 will ensure you don't get any bleeding problems at greater render distances.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_min_mip
Function.Description: With this function you can get the minimum mipmap level which is currently used, where a value of 0 is the highest resolution, 1 is to use the first mipmap, 2 is the second, etc.

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_min_mip_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can get the minimum mipmap level which is currently used for a given shader sampler.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_mip_bias
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the mipmap bias value, where a value of 0 equals no bias, 1 equals the first mipmap, 2 equals the second mipmap, etc. This controls the rate at which the mip map is swapped and will generally make rendered textures blurrier the higher the value and the greater the "distance" being viewed. Note that this can return negative values too, in which case rendered textures will be sharper over a greater distance the lower the value.

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_mip_bias_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the mipmap bias value for a given shader sampler. Note that this can return negative values too, in which case shader textures will be sharper over a greater distance the lower the value.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_mip_enable
Function.Description: With this function you can get whether mipmapping is switched off, switched on for everything or switched on only for texture groups selected in the Texture Group Manager.

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_mip_enable_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can get whether mipmapping is switched off, switched on for everything or switched on only for texture groups selected in the Texture Group Manager on a shader sampler.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_mip_filter
Function.Description: With this function you can get the current mip filter mode.

Function.Name: gpu_get_tex_mip_filter_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can get the current mip filter mode for a given shader sampler.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_max_aniso
Function.Description: With this function you can set the current maximum level of anisotropy when using the tf_anisotropic filter mode (see gpu_get_tex_mip_filter() for more information). The input value must range between 1 and 16.
Function.Parameter: The maximum level for anisotropic filtering (default: 16)

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_max_aniso_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can set the maximum level of anisotropy when using the tf_anisotropic filter mode (see gpu_get_tex_mip_filter() for more information) on a shader sampler.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get
The maximum anisotropic level to use (default: 16).

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_max_mip
Function.Description: With this function you can set the currently set maximum mipmap level which is to be used, where a value of 0 is the highest resolution, 1 is to use the first mipmap, 2 is the second, etc.
Function.Parameter: The maximum mipmap level (default: 16)

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_max_mip_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can get the currently set maximum mipmap level which is to be used for a given shader sampler.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get
The maximum mipmap level value to use (default: 16)

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_min_mip
Function.Description: With this function you can set the minimum mipmap level which is currently used, where a value of 0 is the highest resolution, 1 is to use the first mipmap, 2 is the second, etc.
Function.Parameter: The minimum mipmap level to use

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_min_mip_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can set the minimum mipmap level which is currently used for a given shader sampler.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get
The minimum mipmap level to use

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_mip_bias
Function.Description: With this function you can set the mipmap bias value, where a value of 0 equals no bias, 1 equals the first mipmap, 2 equals the second mipmap, etc.
Function.Parameter: The mipmap bias value to use (default: 0)

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_mip_bias_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can set the mipmap bias value for a given shader sampler.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get
The mipmap bias value to use (default: 0)

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_mip_enable
Function.Description: With this function you can change whether mipmapping is switched off, switched on for everything, or switched on only for texture groups selected in the Texture Group Manager.
Function.Parameter: The mipmap setting (a constant, default: mip_markedonly)

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_mip_enable_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can set whether mipmapping is switched off, switched on for everything or switched on only for texture groups selected in the Texture Group Manager on a shader sampler.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get
The mipmap setting (a constant, default: mip_markedonly)

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_mip_filter
Function.Description: With this function you can set the current mip filter mode to one of the three types supported.
Function.Parameter: The mip filter mode to use (a constant, default: tf_point).

Function.Name: gpu_set_tex_mip_filter_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can set the mip filter mode for a given shader sampler.
Function.Parameter: The index of the shader sampler to get.
The mip filter mode to use (a constant, default: tf_point).

Function.Name: effect_clear
Function.Description: This will clear all particles that are currently visible in the room which have been made using the effect_create_* functions.

Function.Name: effect_create_above
Function.Description:
With this function you can create a simple effect above all instances of your room (it is actually created at a depth of -15000).
If the effect is anything other than ef_rain or ef_snow then you can define an x/y position to create the effect, and the size can be a value of 0, 1, or 2, where 0 is small, 1 is medium and 2 is large.
Function.Parameter: The kind of effect (use one of the constants listed above).
The x positioning of the effect if relevant.
The y positioning of the effect if relevant.
The size of the effect.
The colour of the effect.

Function.Name: effect_create_below
Function.Description:
With this function you can create a simple effect below all instances of your room (it is actually created at a depth of 50).
If the effect is anything other than ef_rain or ef_snow then you can define an x/y position to create the effect, and the size can be a value of 0, 1, or 2, where 0 is small, 1 is medium and 2 is large.
Function.Parameter: The kind of effect (use one of the constants listed above).
The x positioning of the effect if relevant.
The y positioning of the effect if relevant.
The size of the effect.
The colour of the effect.

Function.Name: effect_create_layer
Function.Description:
With this function you can create a simple effect on a specified layer.
If the effect is anything other than ef_rain or ef_snow then you can define an x/y position to create the effect, and the size can be a value of 0, 1, or 2, where 0 is small, 1 is medium and 2 is large.
Function.Parameter: The layer ID (or name) to assign the created effect to.
The kind of effect (use one of the constants listed above).
The x positioning of the effect if relevant.
The y positioning of the effect if relevant.
The size of the effect.
The colour of the effect.

Function.Name: effect_create_depth
Function.Description:
With this function you can create a simple effect at a specified depth.
If the effect is anything other than ef_rain or ef_snow then you can define an x/y position to create the effect, and the size can be a value of 0, 1, or 2, where 0 is small, 1 is medium and 2 is large.
Function.Parameter: The depth to assign the created effect to.
The kind of effect (use one of the constants listed above).
The x positioning of the effect if relevant.
The y positioning of the effect if relevant.
The size of the effect.
The colour of the effect.

Function.Name: part_emitter_burst
Function.Description: This function allows you to set an emitter to burst a specific type of particle and is typically used in alarms and destroy events as it is a one off code that creates the number of particles specified all at once following the distribution, shape and position set by the function part_emitter_region(). Should you need the particles to appear every step, you should be using the function part_emitter_stream() instead.
Function.Parameter: The particle system that the emitter is in.
The index of the emitter to burst from.
The index (type) of the particles to be created.
The number of particles to create.

Function.Name: part_emitter_clear
Function.Description: With this function you can clear the given emitter from the specified particle system back to its default state. This will also stop any particles that are being streamed from the emitter at the time, and if you wish to use the emitter again you will need to set the region position and particle type using the part_emitter_region() function.
Function.Parameter: The particle system that the emitter is in.
The index of the emitter to clear.

Function.Name: part_emitter_create
Function.Description: This function must be used to create a new emitter and assign it to a given particle system. The emitter must be destroyed when no longer being used to prevent memory leaks
Function.Parameter: The particle system to create the emitter in.

Function.Name: part_emitter_destroy
Function.Description: This function will remove the specified emitter from the given system and clear it from memory (this will also stop any particles from being produced by the given emitter, but does NOT remove existing ones from the room). This function should always be called when the given emitter is no longer needed for the system to prevent memory leaks and errors.
Function.Parameter: The particle system to destroy the emitter from.
The index of the emitter to destroy.

Function.Name: part_emitter_destroy_all
Function.Description: This function will remove all defined emitters from the given system and clear them from memory (this will also stop any particles from being produced by the given emitter, but does NOT remove existing ones from the room). This function should always be called when the emitters are no longer needed for the system to prevent memory leaks and errors.
Function.Parameter: The particle system to destroy all emitters from.

Function.Name: part_emitter_enable
Function.Description: With this function you can enable or disable a particle emitter. Disabled particle emitters are not updated nor rendered and they do not spawn new particles.
Function.Parameter: The particle system that the emitter is in.
The index of the emitter to enable or disable.
Enable (true) or disable (false) the particle emitter.

Function.Name: part_emitter_exists
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see if the given particle emitter indexed exists in the given system or not. Note that if the variable being checked is an uninitialised variable (that a particle emitter would otherwise have its index assigned to) this will throw an error.
Function.Parameter: The particle system to check for an emitter.
The index of the emitter to search for.

Function.Name: part_emitter_region
Function.Description: This function is used to set the position of a particle emitter within the current room.
Function.Parameter: The particle system that the emitter is in.
The index of the emitter to set.
The x coordinate of the left side of the region.
The x coordinate of the right side.
The y coordinate of the top of the region.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the region.
The shape of the region.
The distribution style of the particles.

Function.Name: part_emitter_stream
Function.Description: This function allows you to set an emitter to stream a specific type of particle and is typically used in the create event as it is a one-off code that sets the emitter to generate the number of particles specified every step of the game thereafter.
Function.Parameter: The particle system that the emitter is in.
The index of the emitter to burst from.
The index (type) of the particles to be created.
The number of particles to create per step.

Function.Name: part_emitter_delay
Function.Description: With this function you can configure an emitter's delay before it bursts first particles when it is in a stream mode.
Function.Parameter: The particle system that the emitter is in.
The index of the emitter.
The minimum length of the delay.
The maximum length of the delay.
The units that the delay is measured in.

Function.Name: part_emitter_interval
Function.Description: With this function you can configure the interval between individual particle bursts when an emitter is in a stream mode.
Function.Parameter: The particle system that the emitter is in.
The index of the emitter.
The minimum length of the interval.
The maximum length of the interval.
The units that the interval is measured in.

Function.Name: part_emitter_relative
Function.Description: With this function you can enable relative mode for an emitter, which means that the number of particles it burst or streams becomes relative to its area.
Function.Parameter: The particle system that the emitter is in.
The index of the emitter.
Enable (true) or disable (false) relative mode.

Function.Name: part_particles_clear
Function.Description: With this function you can clear all the particles currently created by the system from the room.
