Function.Name: file_bin_rewrite
Function.Description: This function takes the filename handle as returned by the function file_bin_open() and then rewrites the file, clearing it of all previous data to start writing from the beginning of the file.
Function.Parameter: The ID of the file to rewrite.

Function.Name: file_bin_seek
Function.Description: This function moves the current read position within the file to the indicated position.
Function.Parameter: The ID of the file to read from.
The position in the file to move to.

Function.Name: file_bin_size
Function.Description: This function will return the size (in bytes) of a file that has been opened for reading and/or writing.
Function.Parameter: The ID of the file to get the size of.

Function.Name: file_bin_write_byte
Function.Description: This function will write a byte of data to the file identified by the file ID at the current write position.
Function.Parameter: The ID of the file to write to.
The data to write.

Function.Name: base64_decode
Function.Description: This function will convert a string encoded previously using base64 format into standard text.
Function.Parameter: The string to decode.

Function.Name: base64_encode
Function.Description: This function will convert a string into a base64 format encoded string.
Function.Parameter: The string to encode.

Function.Name: json_decode
Function.Description: This function decodes a JSON string and converts it into a DS Map, ready for use in GameMaker.
Function.Parameter: The JSON format string that you are passing to the function for decoding

Function.Name: json_encode
Function.Description: This function takes an existing DS Map and encodes its contents as a JSON string.
Function.Parameter: a DS map with the information to encode (or an array)
Whether of not the result JSON string should be prettified. Defaults to false.

Function.Name: json_parse
Function.Description: This function can be used to parse a JSON string (either previously created using json_stringify() or from any other valid source), and convert it into a collection of arrays or structs, where an array is the equivalent of a JSON array and a struct is the equivalent of a JSON object.
Function.Parameter: The JSON to parse
filter function called for each value element parsed in the data - function takes 2 arguments (key and value) and returns a value (this is the value that is then placed in the final output)
Enable or disable the automatic conversion of strings into handles / int64 / nans and infinities. (default is false)

Function.Name: json_stringify
Function.Description: With this function you can convert single or nested structs and arrays into a valid JSON string.
Function.Parameter: The reference value for a struct or array to convert into a JSON string
Whether of not the result JSON string should be prettified. Defaults to false.
filter function called for each value element encoded in the output - function takes 2 arguments (key and value) and returns a value (this is the value that is then placed in the final output)

Function.Name: load_csv
Function.Description: This function will load a CSV format file and convert it into a DS grid, returning the unique ID value for the grid created.
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to open (as a string)

Function.Name: md5_file
Function.Description: This function generates a unique MD5 hash for the given file which can be stored for later use.
Function.Parameter: The file to generate the MD5 hash for.

Function.Name: md5_string_unicode
Function.Description: This function will take an input Unicode string (which is 16bits for each character) and return the 32-character hexadecimal MD5 hash that is unique to that string.
Function.Parameter: The string to hash.

Function.Name: md5_string_utf8
Function.Description: This function will take an input UTF-8 string (which has a variable number of bytes per character) and return the 32-character hexadecimal MD5 hash that is unique to that string.
Function.Parameter: The string to hash.

Function.Name: sha1_file
Function.Description: This function will take an input file and return a 160 bit hash value in ASCII format unique to that file to be used for integrity verification at any later date.
Function.Parameter: The file to generate the sha1 hash for.

Function.Name: sha1_string_unicode
Function.Description: This function will take an input Unicode string and returns a 160 bit hash value in ASCII format.
Function.Parameter: The string to hash.

Function.Name: sha1_string_utf8
Function.Description: This function will take an input UTF-8 string (which has a variable number of bytes per character) and returns a 160 bit hash value in ASCII format.
Function.Parameter: The string to hash.

Function.Name: zip_unzip
Function.Description: This function will open a stored zip file and extract its contents to the given directory.
Function.Parameter: The zip file to open
The target directory to extract the files to

Function.Name: zip_unzip_async
Function.Description: This function will open a stored zip file and extract its contents to the given directory asynchronously.
Function.Parameter: The zip file to open
The target directory to extract the files to

Function.Name: zip_create
Function.Description: This function will create a new zip object which files can be added to.

Function.Name: zip_add_file
Function.Description: This function will add a reference to the specified source file with the desired destination path in the specified zip file.
Function.Parameter: The zip object which the file should be added to.
The destination path within the zip file.
The path to the source file to be added.

Function.Name: zip_save
Function.Description: This function will save a zip object to the specified path.
Function.Parameter: The zip object to be saved.
The path the zip should be saved to.

Function.Name: directory_create
Function.Description: This function will create a directory with the given name in the save area.
Function.Parameter: The name of the directory to create.

Function.Name: directory_destroy
Function.Description: This function will remove a directory with the given name in the save area.
Function.Parameter: The name of the directory to remove.

Function.Name: directory_exists
Function.Description: This function will return true if the indicated directory exists or false if it does not.
Function.Parameter: The name of the directory to look for.

Function.Name: filename_change_ext
Function.Description: This function returns the indicated file name with the extension (including the dot) changed to the new extension.
Function.Parameter: The file to use.
The new extension to use.

Function.Name: filename_dir
Function.Description: This function returns the directory part of the indicated file name, which normally is the same as the path except for the final backslash.
Function.Parameter: The file to use.

Function.Name: filename_drive
Function.Description: This function returns the drive information of the filename.
Function.Parameter: The file to use.

Function.Name: filename_ext
Function.Description: This function returns the extension part of the indicated file name, including the leading dot.
Function.Parameter: The file to use.

Function.Name: filename_name
Function.Description: This function returns the name part of the indicated file, with the extension but without the path.
Function.Parameter: The file to use.

Function.Name: filename_path
Function.Description: This function returns the path part of the indicated file path, including the final backslash.
Function.Parameter: The file name and path to use.

Function.Name: file_attributes
Function.Description: You can use this function to check if the given file has all the attributes that you specify.
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to check.
The attributes to check for.

Function.Name: file_copy
Function.Description: This function will copy the specified file, giving it the new name that you choose.
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to copy.
The name of the new, copied, file.

Function.Name: file_delete
Function.Description: This function will delete the specified file from the system.
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to delete.

Function.Name: file_exists
Function.Description: This function will return true if the specified file exists and false if it does not.
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to check for.

Function.Name: file_find_close
Function.Description: This function must be called after handling files opened using file_find_first() and file_find_next() functions to free memory.

Function.Name: file_find_first
Function.Description: This function returns the name of the first file that satisfies the mask and attributes, or an empty string if no such file exists.
Function.Parameter: The mask to use for searching.
The specific file attribute to look for.

Function.Name: file_find_next
Function.Description: This function returns the name of the next file that satisfies the previously given mask and the attributes (defined by file_find_first), or an empty string if no such file exists.

Function.Name: file_rename
Function.Description: This function will rename the specified file with the specified name.
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to change.
The new name to give the file.

Function.Name: get_open_filename
Function.Description: This function opens a dialogue and asks the player for a filename to open with the given filter.
Function.Parameter: The file type filter and/or name.
The suggested filename to use.

Function.Name: get_open_filename_ext
Function.Description: This function opens a dialogue and asks the player for a filename to open with the given filter.
Function.Parameter: The file type filter and/or name.
The suggested filename to use.
The directory to start the search from.
The caption for the window.

Function.Name: get_save_filename
Function.Description: This function opens a dialogue and asks the player for a filename to save to with the given filter.
Function.Parameter: The file type filter and/or name.
The suggested filename to use.

Function.Name: get_save_filename_ext
Function.Description: This function opens a dialogue and asks the player for a filename to save to with the given filter.
Function.Parameter: The file type filter and/or name.
The suggested filename to use.
The directory to start the search from.
The caption for the window.

Function.Name: ini_close
Function.Description: This function should be called the moment you are finished reading or writing to any open ini file.

Function.Name: ini_key_delete
Function.Description: With this function you can remove the selected key (and its corresponding value) from an ini file.
Function.Parameter: The section to delete a key from.
The key to delete.

Function.Name: ini_key_exists
Function.Description: This function checks to see if a key exists in the currently open ini and will return true if it does or false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: The section in the open .ini file to check a key in.
The key to check for.

Function.Name: ini_open
Function.Description: This function opens a new INI file for reading/writing, closing the currently open INI file if there is any.
Function.Parameter: The filename for the .ini file.

Function.Name: ini_open_from_string
Function.Description: This function will create an ini file from a string and open it for reading/writing.
Function.Parameter: The string containing all the ini information.

Function.Name: ini_read_real
Function.Description: You can use this function to read a number from an ini data file.
Function.Parameter: The section of the .ini to read from.
The key within the relevant section of the .ini to read from.
The value to return if a value is not found in the defined place (or the .ini file does not exist). Must be a real number.

Function.Name: ini_read_string
Function.Description: You can use this function to read a string (text) from an ini data file.
Function.Parameter: The section of the .ini to read from.
The key within the relevant section of the .ini to read from.
The string to return if a string is not found in the defined place (or the .ini file does not exist). Must be a string.

Function.Name: ini_section_delete
Function.Description: With this function you can delete a whole section of an ini file, which will also remove all key-value pairs that are associated with it.
Function.Parameter: The section to delete.

Function.Name: ini_section_exists
Function.Description: This function checks to see if a section exists in the currently open ini and will return true if it does or false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: The section in the open .ini file to check for.

Function.Name: ini_write_real
Function.Description: You can use this function to write a value (numeric) to an ini data file.
Function.Parameter: The section of the .ini to write to.
The key within the relevant section of the .ini to write to.
The real value to write to the relevant destination.

Function.Name: ini_write_string
Function.Description: You can use this function to write a string (text) to an ini data file.
Function.Parameter: The section of the .ini to write to.
The key within the relevant section of the .ini to write to.
The string to write to the relevant destination.

Function.Name: file_text_close
Function.Description: Once you have finished working with a given file (whether reading from it or writing to it), you must close the file again using this function, or else you risk losing the information contained within.
Function.Parameter: The id of the file to close.

Function.Name: file_text_eof
Function.Description: This function returns true when the end of a given opened text file has been reached or false if not.
Function.Parameter: The id of the file to check.

Function.Name: file_text_eoln
Function.Description: With this function you can get GameMaker to check the currently opened file to see if the line being read has finished.
Function.Parameter: The id of the file to check.

Function.Name: file_text_open_append
Function.Description: This function opens the text file with the indicated filename for writing (if the file does not exist, it is created), returning the unique id of the file that which should be stored in a variable as it will be used for all further actions to do with that file.
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to append to.

Function.Name: file_text_open_from_string
Function.Description: This function will create a text file from a string and open it for reading, returning the file "handle" that should be used in all further file function calls to read from this file.
Function.Parameter: The string to create the file from.

Function.Name: file_text_open_read
Function.Description: This function opens the text file with the indicated filename for reading only, returning the unique id of the file that which should be stored in a variable as it will be used for all further actions to do with that file. If the file does not exists then the function will return the value -1.
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to read from.

Function.Name: file_text_open_write
Function.Description: This function opens the text file with the indicated filename for writing only (if the file does not exist, it is created), returning the unique id of the file that which should be stored in a variable as it will be used for all further actions to do with that file. Note that if the file can't be created (because of an illegal filename, for example) the function will return -1.
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to write to.

Function.Name: file_text_readln
Function.Description: With this function you can skip the remainder of the current line from a given opened text file and move to the start of the next one. The function will also return the full line as a string, making it an easy way to read complete "chunks" of data for parsing later.
Function.Parameter: The id of the file to read from.

Function.Name: file_text_read_real
Function.Description: With this function you can read a real number value from a text file and the function returns that value to be used or stored in a variable.
Function.Parameter: The id of the file to read from.

Function.Name: file_text_read_string
Function.Description: With this function you can read a string from a text file and the function returns that value to be used or stored in a variable.
Function.Parameter: The id of the file to read from.

Function.Name: file_text_writeln
Function.Description: With this function you can write a new line to an opened text file. In this way you can skip lines or write information on a line by line basis.
Function.Parameter: The id of the file to edit.

Function.Name: file_text_write_real
Function.Description: With this function you can write a number to the previously opened text file. Note that as the value to be written can be a real number, all decimals will be written with a "." point as separator.
Function.Parameter: The id of the file to edit.
The real value to write to the file.

Function.Name: file_text_write_string
Function.Description: With this function you can write a string to a previously opened text file.
Function.Parameter: The id of the file to edit.
The string to write to the file.

Function.Name: device_get_tilt_x
Function.Description: This function returns a value between -1 and 1 depending upon the angle of "tilt" of the device. The actual correlation between degrees of tilt and the value returned depends on the device and OS that it uses, but generally a value of 1 or -1 is the same as +/-90.

Function.Name: device_get_tilt_y
Function.Description: This function returns a value between -1 and 1 depending upon the angle of "tilt" of the device. The actual correlation between degrees of tilt and the value returned depends on the device and OS that it uses, but generally a value of 1 or -1 is the same as +/-90.

Function.Name: device_get_tilt_z
Function.Description: This function returns a value between -1 and 1 depending upon the angle of "tilt" of the device. The actual correlation between degrees of tilt and the value returned depends on the device and OS that it uses, but generally a value of 1 or -1 is the same as +/-90.

Function.Name: device_is_keypad_open
Function.Description: This does a check of the device for a keypad and if one is available it returns true, otherwise it returns false. Please note that this function is mainly for use with Android devices

Function.Name: device_mouse_check_button
Function.Description: This function returns true or false depending on whether the given mouse button is being held down on the given device.
Function.Parameter: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked
The button of the device that is being checked.

Function.Name: device_mouse_check_button_pressed
Function.Description: This function returns true or false depending on whether the device that you specify has been "touched" (clicked) or not.
Function.Parameter: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.
The button of the device that is being checked.

Function.Name: device_mouse_check_button_released
Function.Description: This function returns true or false depending on whether the device touch that you specify has been released or not.
Function.Parameter: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.
The button of the device that is being checked.

Function.Name: device_mouse_dbclick_enable
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the device to detect a double tap of the mb_left (left mouse button) as an mb_right (right mouse button) tap or not. By default this is set to true, meaning that every time the user taps the device screen twice quickly and consecutively, the return value is the same as if the right mouse button had been clicked. When this is on, the first tap will be detected as mb_left, and the second as mb_right, so make sure that any code you use takes this into account.
Function.Parameter: Set double-click detection on (true) or off (false).

Function.Name: device_mouse_raw_x
Function.Description:
This function returns the raw x position of a touch on the device. What this means is that it returns the actual device definition of the x position that is being touched, not the GameMaker one, and as such will ignore things like view position and scaling.
Note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs.
Function.Parameter: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

Function.Name: device_mouse_raw_y
Function.Description:
This function returns raw y position of the touch on a device. What this means is that it returns the actual device definition of the y position that is being touched, not the GameMaker one, and as such will ignore things like view position and scaling.
Note that the maximum number of device touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs.
Function.Parameter: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

Function.Name: device_mouse_x
Function.Description: This function returns the x position of a touch on the device. If you are running this on a the HTML5 or PC and Mac modules then this value is updated constantly, as long as the device (usually a mouse) is plugged in, however for mobile devices, this will only be updated while the screen is being touched.
Function.Parameter: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

Function.Name: device_mouse_x_to_gui
Function.Description:
This function returns the x position of the touch on the device in relation to the GUI layer. If you are running this on a the HTML5 or PC and Mac modules then this value is updated constantly, as long as the device (usually a mouse) is plugged in, however for mobile devices, this will only be updated while the screen is being touched.
Note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs. Also note that on HTML5 only "device 0" will function correctly and other devices may give wrong values.
Function.Parameter: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

Function.Name: device_mouse_y
Function.Description:
This function returns the y position of a touch on the device. If you are running this on a the HTML5 or PC and Mac modules then this value is updated constantly, as long as the device (usually a mouse) is plugged in, however for mobile devices, this will only be updated while the screen is being touched.
Note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs. Also note that on HTML5 only "device 0" will function correctly and other devices may give wrong values.
Function.Parameter: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

Function.Name: device_mouse_y_to_gui
Function.Description: This function returns the y position of the touch on the device in relation to the GUI layer.
Function.Parameter: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

Function.Name: gamepad_axis_count
Function.Description: This function will return the number of "axis" controls on the device being checked. These controls are the analogue direction "thumbsticks" on most controllers.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

Function.Name: gamepad_enumerate
Function.Description: Currently only functional on Android, this function will enumerate gamepads to detect any newly added gamepads and remove any recently removed ones without the need for BLUETOOTH_CONNECT permission.

Function.Name: gamepad_axis_value
Function.Description: You can use this function to get the value of the different axes from a given gamepad slot. The returned value will be between -1 and 1 for each of the available horizontal and vertical axes.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.
The axis index to check.

Function.Name: gamepad_button_check
Function.Description: This function will return true or false depending on whether the given gamepad button is detected as being held down or not.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.
Which gamepad button constant to check for.

Function.Name: gamepad_button_check_pressed
Function.Description: This function will return true or false depending on whether the given gamepad button is detected as having been pressed or not.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.
Which gamepad button constant to check for.

Function.Name: gamepad_button_check_released
Function.Description: This function will return true or false depending on whether the given gamepad button is detected as having been released or not.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.
Which gamepad button constant to check for.

Function.Name: gamepad_button_count
Function.Description: This function will return the total number of buttons available for the gamepad connected to the given device "slot".
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

Function.Name: gamepad_button_value
Function.Description: With this function you can get the current value of an analogue button, from 0 to 1, where 0 is no pressure and 1 is full pressure.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.
Which gamepad button constant to check for.

Function.Name: gamepad_get_axis_deadzone
Function.Description: This function can be used to get the "dead zone" value of the joystick axis. The function will return a value between 0 to 1, where value reflects the threshold under which the joystick axis is considered to be at 0.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

Function.Name: gamepad_get_button_threshold
Function.Description: This function can be used to detect the current threshold setting of the analogue buttons for a given device. The default threshold for all analogue buttons is 0.5, with the range being from 0 to 1. The threshold defines at what point the button is considered as being "pressed" for games that require them to act as a digital button.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

Function.Name: gamepad_get_description
Function.Description: This function will return a string with the description of the given gamepad. This string is hardware dependent and the returned value will depend on the gamepad plugged into the device "slot" that is being checked.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad "slot" to get the name of.

Function.Name: gamepad_get_device_count
Function.Description: This function will tell you one of two things; either the number of game pads connected, or the number of available "slots" for game pads to be connected to.

Function.Name: gamepad_get_guid
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the GUID for the gamepad connected to the given slot index.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad "slot" index to check

Function.Name: gamepad_get_mapping
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the mapping string for the gamepad.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad index "slot" to get the mapping from.

Function.Name: gamepad_get_option
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the given option value. The available option string will depend on the platform that the project is being run on.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.
The name of the option to get the value from

Function.Name: gamepad_hat_count
Function.Description:
This function will return the total number of hats available for the gamepad connected to the given device "slot". Hats generally refer to up/down/left/right buttons.
Note that on the Windows target, hats are only available on DirectInput controllers (so, from slot 4 upwards).
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

Function.Name: gamepad_hat_value
Function.Description: With this function you can get the current value of a gamepad "hat".
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.
Which gamepad hat (or hats) to check for.

Function.Name: gamepad_is_connected
Function.Description:
This function will return whether a gamepad is connected to the given "slot" (returns true) or not (returns false).
Note that there may be a slight delay between the user connecting the gamepad and GameMaker detecting it as being connected (this is especially the case when dealing with Bluetooth connected controllers).
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad "slot" to check.

Function.Name: gamepad_is_supported
Function.Description: With this function you can find out whether the target platform supports game pads (returns true) or not (returns false).

Function.Name: gamepad_remove_mapping
Function.Description: This function can be used to remove the current device mapping from the given gamepad slot index. Once called, the slot index will need to be remapped using the gamepad_test_mapping() function if you want to be able to be able to use the gamepad constants to detect input correctly (direct input can always be retrieved using the gamepad_axis/button/hat_count() and gamepad_axis/button/hat_value() functions together).
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad index "slot" to remove the mapping from.

Function.Name: gamepad_set_axis_deadzone
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the "dead zone" of the joystick axis. You specify the device slot to set, and then set a value from 0 to 1 and if the input amount is lower than the given value, the joystick axis is considered to be at 0. Note that this is a global setting that will affect all axes of all joysticks connected to the device slot specified.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.
The dead zone value from 0 to 1.

Function.Name: gamepad_set_button_threshold
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the current threshold setting of the analogue buttons for a given device. The default threshold for all analogue buttons is 0.5, with the range being from 0 to 1. The threshold defines at what point the button is considered as being "pressed" for games that require them to act as a digital button. Note that this function will affect the check, pressed and released states for analogue buttons, but will not affect the value returned by the function gamepad_button_check(), which will always return the raw value for the button.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.
The new threshold value (from 0 - 1, default 0.5).

Function.Name: gamepad_set_colour
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the colour of the LEDs within a PlayStation controller. You specify the device slot to set, and then give a colour, which can be any of the colour constants, a colour value created using the specific colour functions or a HEX value(like $FFFFFFF).
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to set.
The colour to use.

Function.Name: gamepad_set_option
Function.Description: This function can be used to set any of the available gamepad options. The available option string will depend on the platform that the project is being run on.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to set.
The name of the option to set
The value to set the option to (can be boolean, real, integer or string)

Function.Name: gamepad_set_vibration
Function.Description: With this function you can set the vibration of the gamepad motors, with either motor using a value from 0 (no vibration) to 1 (full vibration). Note that there is no time limit on this function, so you will need to use a variable or an alarm to switch off the vibration (set motors to 0) after a given time has passed, otherwise the gamepad will continue to vibrate indefinitely.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.
The amount of vibration from the left motor from 0 to 1.
The amount of vibration from the right motor from 0 to 1.

Function.Name: gamepad_test_mapping
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the gamepad mapping on those targets that permit it.
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad index "slot" to set.
The map string to use.

Function.Name: gesture_double_tap_distance
Function.Description: This function is used to set the distance within which you have to touch/click the screen again after a single tap in order to trigger a Double Tap Gesture. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.
Function.Parameter: The distance (in inches) to set for double tap gesture event detection.

Function.Name: gesture_double_tap_time
Function.Description: This function is used to set the time it takes between two touches/clicks to trigger a Double Tap Gesture event. The time is measured in seconds and has a default value of 0.16.
Function.Parameter: The time (in seconds) to set for double tap gesture event detection.

Function.Name: gesture_drag_distance
Function.Description: This function is used to set the distance it takes for a Dragging Gesture event to be triggered by the movement of a touch or click. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.
Function.Parameter: The distance (in inches) to set for drag gesture event detection.

Function.Name: gesture_drag_time
Function.Description: This function is used to set the time it takes for a Drag Gesture event to be triggered by a touch or click. This time will also affect how the Tap Event is triggered as a touch/click and release before this time is up will be considered a Tap. The time is measured in seconds and has a default value of 0.16.
Function.Parameter: The time (in seconds) to set for drag gesture event detection.

Function.Name: gesture_flick_speed
Function.Description: This function is used to set the speed required for a Flick Gesture event to be triggered when a touch or click is released. The speed is measured in inches per second and has a default value of 2.0.
Function.Parameter: The speed (in inches per second) to set for flick gesture event detection.

Function.Name: gesture_get_double_tap_distance
Function.Description: This function is used to get the distance within which you have to touch/click the screen again after a single tap in order to trigger a Double Tap Gesture. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.

Function.Name: gesture_get_double_tap_time
Function.Description: This function is used to get the time it takes between two touches/clicks to trigger a Double Tap Gesture event. The time is measured in seconds and has a default value of 0.16.

Function.Name: gesture_get_drag_distance
Function.Description: This function is used to get the distance it takes for a Dragging Gesture event to be triggered by the movement of a touch or click. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.

Function.Name: gesture_get_drag_time
Function.Description: This function is used to get the time it takes for a Drag Start Gesture event to be triggered by a touch or click. This time will also affect how the Tap Event is triggered as a touch/click and release before this time is up will be considered a Tap. The time is measured in seconds and has a default value of 0.16.

Function.Name: gesture_get_flick_speed
Function.Description: This function is used to get the speed required for a Flick Gesture event to be triggered when a touch or click is released. The speed is measured in inches per second and has a default value of 2.0.

Function.Name: gesture_get_pinch_angle_away
Function.Description: This function is used to get the angle within which a touch must be moving away from another touch before a Pinch Out Gesture may potentially be started. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 45.

Function.Name: gesture_get_pinch_angle_towards
Function.Description: This function is used to get the angle within which a touch must be moving towards another touch before a Pinch In Gesture may potentially be started. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 45.

Function.Name: gesture_get_pinch_distance
Function.Description: This function is used to get the distance within which you have to touch/click the screen and move with two fingers before you trigger a Pinch Gesture. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.

Function.Name: gesture_get_rotate_time
Function.Description: This function is used to get the angle which a pair of touches must exceed in order to trigger a Rotate Start Gesture. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 5.

Function.Name: gesture_get_tap_count
Function.Description: This function is used to check whether tap counting is enabled or disabled. You can enable or disable tap counting using the function gesture_tap_count().

Function.Name: gesture_pinch_angle_away
Function.Description: This function is used to set the angle within which a touch must be moving away from another touch before a Pinch Out Gesture may potentially be started. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 45.

Function.Name: gesture_pinch_angle_towards
Function.Description: This function is used to set the angle within which a touch must be moving towards another touch before a Pinch In Gesture may potentially be started. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 45.

Function.Name: gesture_pinch_distance
Function.Description: This function is used to set the distance within which you have to touch/click the screen and move with two fingers before you trigger a Pinch Gesture. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.

Function.Name: gesture_rotate_angle
Function.Description: This function is used to set the angle which a pair of touches must exceed in order to trigger a Rotate Start Gesture. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 5.

Function.Name: gesture_rotate_time
Function.Description: This function is used to set the time within which a pair of touches must be rotating in a consistent direction for a Rotate Start Gesture to be triggered. The time is measured in seconds and has a default value of 0.16s.

Function.Name: gesture_tap_count
Function.Description: This function is used to set whether tap counting is enabled or disabled. When set to true tap counting is enabled, and when set to false it is disabled, although you can check which state it is in using the function gesture_get_tap_count(). Note that this is enabled by default.
Function.Parameter: Enable (set to true) or disable (set to false) tap counting.

Function.Name: io_clear
Function.Description: This function will clear the current keyboard and mouse states.

Function.Name: keyboard_check
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see if a key is held down or not. Unlike the keyboard_check_pressed() or keyboard_check_released() functions which are only triggered once when the key is pressed or released, this function is triggered every step that the key is held down for.
Function.Parameter: The key to check the down state of.

Function.Name: keyboard_check_direct
Function.Description: This function will return true if the key with the particular keycode is pressed, or false if it is not, by checking the hardware directly.
Function.Parameter: The key to check the down state of.

Function.Name: keyboard_check_pressed
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see if a key has been pressed or not. Unlike the keyboard_check() function, this function will only run once for every time the key is pressed down, so for it to trigger again, the key must be first released and then pressed again.
Function.Parameter: The key to check the pressed state of.

Function.Name: keyboard_check_released
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see if a key has been released or not. Unlike the keyboard_check() function, this function will only run once for every time the key is lifted, so for it to trigger again, the key must be first pressed and then released again.
Function.Parameter: The key to check the released state of.

Function.Name: keyboard_clear
Function.Description: With this function you can clear the current keyboard state, which essentially means that if the key is being held down, it will no longer be recognised until it is released again (which won't trigger the Keyboard Key Released event either on this occasion) and pressed again.
Function.Parameter: The key to clear.

Function.Name: keyboard_get_map
Function.Description: Sometimes you may wish to get the ASCII code for a mapped key (to see if it is already mapped, for example) which is what this function returns.
Function.Parameter: This is the key that you wish to get the mapped value from

Function.Name: keyboard_get_numlock
Function.Description: You can use this function to find the status of the keypad number lock with true being returned for on, and false returned for off.

Function.Name: keyboard_key_press
Function.Description: With this function you can simulate the press of any key on the keyboard.
Function.Parameter: The key to simulate a press of.

Function.Name: keyboard_key_release
Function.Description: With this function you can simulate the release of any key on the keyboard.
Function.Parameter: The key to simulate a release of.

Function.Name: keyboard_set_map
Function.Description: This function maps a keyboard key to another one using the keycode value so that any input from either key will be interpreted as the same.
Function.Parameter: This is the key that key2 is to be mapped to
This is the key that is to be mapped

Function.Name: keyboard_set_numlock
Function.Description: You can use this function to switch the keypad number-lock on or off (set to true for on, and false for off).
Function.Parameter: Set this to true for "on" and false for "off"

Function.Name: keyboard_unset_map
Function.Description: With this function you can clear all re-mapped keys so that they return to their default state, i.e.: all keys to map to themselves.

Function.Name: mouse_check_button
Function.Description: This function will return true if the mouse button being checked is held down or false if it is not.
Function.Parameter: Which mouse button constant to check for.

Function.Name: mouse_check_button_pressed
Function.Description: This function will return true if the mouse button being checked has been pressed or false if it has not. This function will only be triggered once for any mouse button when it is first pressed and to trigger it again the button will need to have been released and pressed again. Note that it will be considered triggered for the duration of the step, and for all instances that have any mouse events or that use this same function.
Function.Parameter: Which mouse button constant to check for.

Function.Name: mouse_check_button_released
Function.Description: This function will return true if the mouse button being checked has been released or false if it has not. This function will only be triggered once for any mouse button when it is released and to trigger it again the button will need to have been pressed and released again.
Function.Parameter: Which mouse button constant to check for.

Function.Name: mouse_clear
Function.Description: This function will clear the current state of the given mouse button. This means that checks for it being held down will not return true until the player releases the button and presses it again (but the release state will still be detected if the clear is done while the mouse button is being held down).
Function.Parameter: Which mouse button constant to check for.

Function.Name: mouse_wheel_down
Function.Description: This function returns true if the mouse wheel is being rotated downwards and false otherwise.

Function.Name: mouse_wheel_up
Function.Description: This function returns true if the mouse wheel is being rotated upwards and false otherwise.

Function.Name: keyboard_virtual_height
Function.Description: This function will return the current height in pixels of the virtual keyboard, based on the size of the display. If the keyboard is not visible, 0 will be returned.

Function.Name: keyboard_virtual_hide
Function.Description: This function can be used to hide the virtual keyboard on the device running the game. Calling this function will generate a System Asynchronous Event.

Function.Name: keyboard_virtual_show
Function.Description: This function can be used to show the virtual keyboard on the device running the game.
Function.Parameter: Determines the keyset available on the virtual keyboard.
Determines what is shown on the return/action key of the virtual keyboard.
Determines how/if the words typed via the virtual keyboard will be autocapitalized.
Set to true/false to enable/disable predictive text input.

Function.Name: keyboard_virtual_status
Function.Description: This function can be used to get the status of the virtual keyboard on the device running the game. The function will return true if the OS virtual keyboard is visible/being shown or false if it is hidden/hiding.

Function.Name: keyboard_virtual_set_position
Function.Description: This Windows only function can be used to set the position of the virtual keyboard on the device running the game. The coordinates passed in are in display coordinates (use application_get_position() to find the game's position in this space).
Function.Parameter: x coordinate of the requested position.
y coordinate of the requested position.

Function.Name: virtual_key_add
Function.Description: This function adds a virtual key that covers a portion of the screen area, mapping "touches" of this area to a keyboard key.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate (left side) of the virtual key on the screen
The y coordinate (top side) of the virtual key on the screen
The width of the virtual key
The height of the virtual key
Which keyboard key event should be triggered by touching this area

Function.Name: virtual_key_delete
Function.Description: This function deletes a previously added virtual key.
Function.Parameter: The index of the virtual key to delete.

Function.Name: virtual_key_hide
Function.Description: This function hides the coloured rectangle that's drawn to represent the given virtual key on the screen.
Function.Parameter: The index of the virtual key to hide.

Function.Name: virtual_key_show
Function.Description: This function draws a coloured rectangle to represent the given virtual key on the screen.
Function.Parameter: The index of the virtual key to show.

Function.Name: gc_collect
Function.Description: With this function you can trigger the garbage collector, forcing it to run at the end of the current frame (step). It is worth noting that the garbage collector does not need to be active for this to work.

Function.Name: gc_enable
Function.Description: With this function you can enable or disable the garbage collector. Calling the function with true as the argument enables it and using false disables it (not recommended). It is enabled by default.
Function.Parameter: enable (true) or disable (false) the garbage collector.

Function.Name: gc_get_stats
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve information about the current state of the garbage collector.

Function.Name: gc_get_target_frame_time
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the current target frame value for the garbage collector. The value returned is in microseconds (where 1,000,000 microseconds equals one second) and the default target frame time is 100 microseconds. If you wish to change this value then you should use the function gc_target_frame_time().

Function.Name: gc_is_enabled
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see if the garbage collector is enabled or not.

Function.Name: gc_target_frame_time
Function.Description: With this function you can indicate to the garbage collector that it should aim to spend no more than the time specified running each frame. The function takes a time value specified in microseconds (where 1,000,000 microseconds equals one second) and the default target frame time is 100 microseconds.
Function.Parameter: The target time - in microseconds - that the garbage collector should work each frame

Function.Name: weak_ref_create
Function.Description: With this function you can check the weak reference to a struct to see if it is still "alive" or not. Note that if you supply a value that is not a weak reference, the function will return undefined.
Function.Parameter: The struct that you want to create a weak reference for

Function.Name: weak_ref_any_alive
Function.Description: With this function you can check the weak reference to various structs to see if it they are still "alive" or not. Note that if you supply an array where any of the values are not a weak references, the function will return undefined.
Function.Parameter: The weak reference to the struct you want to check.
OPTIONAL! The index into the array to start checking from
OPTIONAL! The number of positions from the given index to check

Function.Name: game_end
Function.Description: With this function you can end the game (and the Game End Event will be triggered). This will not happen instantaneously, but rather at the end of the current step, so any code you have in the same step after this function has been called will still run.
Function.Parameter: The return code of the application, will default to 0.

Function.Name: game_get_speed
Function.Description:
This function can be used to get the game speed as either the number of game frames to run per second or as the number of microseconds per game frame.
Note that this is not the actual running speed FPS value (for that use the fps_real variable) but rather the number of game frames (FPS) that the game will attempt to maintain each second, or the length of each game frame in microseconds that the game will try to maintain (MPF).
Function.Parameter: The type of method used to get the game speed.

Function.Name: game_load
Function.Description: This is a legacy function that can be used to load a game that has been previously saved using game_save(). Note that it will restore the version of the game that was used to create the save, so any updates made after it will not be visible. For more info, read the page on game_save().
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to load.

Function.Name: game_load_buffer
Function.Description: With this function you can load a game state that has been saved previously. The game is loaded from a previously created "grow" buffer and the buffer must have had a game state saved to it using game_save_buffer() function.
Function.Parameter: The buffer id to load from.

Function.Name: game_restart
Function.Description: With this function you can restart the game. This is essentially the same as running the game for the first time and so the Game Start Event will be triggered, as well as the Game End Event.

Function.Name: game_save
Function.Description: This is a legacy function that can be used to save the current state of the game, and is not recommended for use anymore. Use the File functions instead to create a custom save system where you only save and load specific game data.
Function.Parameter: The name of the file to save the game to.

Function.Name: game_save_buffer
Function.Description: This is a variant of the game_save() function, so please read its page first as it contains important information related to its use and to this function's use as well.
Function.Parameter: The buffer id to save to.

Function.Name: game_set_speed
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the game speed. You can set this in one of two ways: as game frames per second (FPS) or as microseconds per game frame (MPF).
Function.Parameter: The new game speed (as either FPS or MPF).
The type of method used to set the game speed.

Function.Name: game_change
Function.Description: This function allows you to close the currently running title and launch another title, it will only work in VM and on certain platforms it will only work in a package build and not in run/debug.
Function.Parameter: The directory in which the new game will launch.
Command line parameters to be passed to the new game.

Function.Name: highscore_add
Function.Description: With this function you can add a name and a score to the internal global high score list. There is no need to check the value to see if it is high enough to enter into the score list as GameMaker will only store those values that are greater than the tenth position stored.
Function.Parameter: The string (name) to attribute the score to
The number (score) to add.

Function.Name: highscore_value
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the score value that has been stored in the high score list at the given position. If no score has been entered, the function will return 0.
Function.Parameter: The place on the table (1-10).

Function.Name: highscore_name
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the name string that has been stored in the high score list at the given position. If no name has been entered, the string "Unknown" will be returned.
Function.Parameter: The place on the table (1-10).

Function.Name: angle_difference
Function.Description: This function returns the smallest difference between the two specified angles, where the difference is calculated from the source angle towards the destination angle.
Function.Parameter: The destination or target angle (in degrees)
The source angle (in degrees)

Function.Name: arccos
Function.Description: This function returns the inverse cosine (in radians) of x, in that if cos(val)=n, arccos(n)=val, and the resulting number will be between 0 and pi.
Function.Parameter: The angle (in radians) to return the inverse cosine of.

Function.Name: arcsin
Function.Description: This function returns the inverse sine (in radians) of x, in that if sin(x)=n, arcsin(n)=x, and the resulting number will be between -pi/2 and pi/2.
Function.Parameter: The value to return the inverse sine of.

Function.Name: arctan
Function.Description: This function returns the inverse tangent (in radians) of x.
Function.Parameter: The angle (in radians) to return the inverse tangent of.

Function.Name: arctan2
Function.Description:
This function returns the inverse tangent (in radians) of a value given as a ratio y/x, where y = opposite side of triangle and x = adjacent side of triangle.
Unlike arctan(), the function arctan2() is valid for all angles and so may be used to convert a vector to an angle without risking division by zero, and it also returns a result in the correct quadrant.
Function.Parameter: The y coordinate to calculate.
The x coordinate to calculate.

Function.Name: cos
Function.Description:
This function returns the cosine of an angle in radians.
In a right-angled triangle the cosine is defined as cos(val) = adjacent / hypotenuse, where val is one of the three angles.
Function.Parameter: The angle (in radians) to return the cosine of.

Function.Name: darccos
Function.Description: This function returns the inverse cosine (in degrees) of x, in that if dcos(val)=n, darccos(n)=val, and the resulting number will be between 0 and 180.
Function.Parameter: The value to return the inverse cosine of.

Function.Name: darcsin
Function.Description: This function returns the inverse sine (in degrees) of x, in that if dsin(x)=n, darcsin(n)=x, and the resulting number will be between -90 and 90.
Function.Parameter: The value to return the inverse sine of.

Function.Name: darctan
Function.Description:
This function returns the inverse tangent (in degrees) of x.
This will accept any number as, unlike dtan(), darctan() asymptotes are on the y axis so it just means you'll never get returned a number greater than 90 or less than -90.
Function.Parameter: The value to return the inverse tangent of.

Function.Name: darctan2
Function.Description:
This function returns the inverse tangent (in degrees) of a value given as y/x, where y = Opposite side of triangle and x = Adjacent side of triangle.
Unlike darctan(), the function darctan2() is valid for all angles and so may be used to convert a vector to an angle without risking division by zero, and it also returns a result in the correct quadrant.
Function.Parameter: The y coordinate to calculate.
The x coordinate to calculate.

Function.Name: dcos
Function.Description:
This function returns the cosine of an angle in degrees.
In a right-angled triangle the cosine is defined as cos(val) = adjacent / hypotenuse, where val is one of the three angles.
Function.Parameter: The angle (in degrees) to return the cosine of.

Function.Name: degtorad
Function.Parameter: The degrees to convert.

Function.Name: distance_to_object
Function.Description: This function calculates the distance from the edge of the bounding box of the calling instance to the nearest edge of the nearest instance of the object specified.
Function.Parameter: The object to check for.

Function.Name: sphere_is_visible
Function.Description: This function checks a sphere of radius r at position x,y,z against the current view frustum. Returns true if the sphere intersects or is contained in the view frustum and false if the sphere is completely outside the view frustum.
Function.Parameter: The x position to check.
The y position to check.
The z position to check.
The radius of the sphere to check.

Function.Name: distance_to_point
Function.Description: This function calculates the distance from the edge of the bounding box of the calling instance to the specified (x , y) position in the room, with the return value being in pixels.
Function.Parameter: The x position to check.
The y position to check.

Function.Name: dot_product
Function.Description: This function returns the dot product of two 2D vectors specified as (x1, y1) and (x2, y2).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the first vector.
The y coordinate of the first vector.
The x coordinate of the second vector.
The y coordinate of the second vector.

Function.Name: dot_product_3d
Function.Description: This function returns the dot product of two 3D vectors specified as (x1, y1, z1) and (x2, y2, z2).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the first vector.
The y coordinate of the first vector.
The z coordinate of the first vector.
The x coordinate of the second vector.
The y coordinate of the second vector.
The z coordinate of the second vector.

Function.Name: dot_product_3d_normalised
Function.Description: This function returns the normalised dot product of two 3D vectors, specified as (x1, y1, z1) and (x2, y2, z2).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the first vector.
The y coordinate of the first vector.
The z coordinate of the first vector.
The x coordinate of the second vector.
The y coordinate of the second vector.
The z coordinate of the second vector.

Function.Name: dot_product_normalised
Function.Description: This function returns the normalised dot product of two 2D vectors specified as (x1, y1) and (x2, y2).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the first vector.
The y coordinate of the first vector.
The x coordinate of the second vector.
The y coordinate of the second vector.

Function.Name: dsin
Function.Description:
This function returns the sine of an angle in degrees.
In a right-angled triangle the sine is defined as sin(val) = opposite / hypotenuse, where val is one of the three angles.
Function.Parameter: The angle (in degrees) to return the sine of.

Function.Name: dtan
Function.Description:
This function returns the tangent of an angle in degrees.
In a right-angled triangle the tangent is defined as tan(val) = opposite / adjacent, where val is one of the three angles.
Function.Parameter: The angle (in degrees) to return the tangent of.

Function.Name: lengthdir_x
Function.Description: This function is used to get the x component of a position "len" pixels from the starting point and in direction "dir".
Function.Parameter: The length away of the point to return.
The direction of the point to return.

Function.Name: lengthdir_y
Function.Description: This function is used to get the y component of a position "len" pixels from the starting point and in direction "dir".
Function.Parameter: The length away of the point to return.
The direction of the point to return.

Function.Name: point_direction
Function.Description: This function returns the direction of a vector formed by the specified components (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) in relation to the fixed x/y coordinates of the room.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the first component of the vector
The y coordinate of the first component of the vector
The x coordinate of the second component of the vector
The y coordinate of the second component of the vector

Function.Name: point_distance
Function.Description: This function returns the length of a vector formed by the specified components (x1, y1) and (x2, y2).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the first component of the vector
The y coordinate of the first component of the vector
The x coordinate of the second component of the vector
The y coordinate of the second component of the vector

Function.Name: point_distance_3d
Function.Description: This function returns the length of a vector formed by the specified components (x1, y1, z1) and (x2, y2, z2).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the first component of the vector
The y coordinate of the first component of the vector
The z coordinate of the first component of the vector
The x coordinate of the second component of the vector
The y coordinate of the second component of the vector
The z coordinate of the second component of the vector

Function.Name: radtodeg
Function.Parameter: The radians to convert.

Function.Name: sin
Function.Description:
This function returns the sine of an angle in radians.
In a right-angled triangle the sine is defined as sin(val) = opposite / hypotenuse, where val is one of the three angles.
Function.Parameter: The angle (in radians) to return the sine of.

Function.Name: tan
Function.Description:
This function returns the tangent of an angle in radians.
In a right-angled triangle the tangent is defined as tan(val) = opposite / adjacent, where val is one of the three angles.
Function.Parameter: The angle (in radians) to return the tangent of.

Function.Name: date_compare_date
Function.Description:
With this function you can check two dates to see which one is the earlier or later than the other.
The function returns -1 if date1 is earlier, 0 if both dates are the same, and 1 if date1 is later.
Function.Parameter: The first date.
The date to compare it to.

Function.Name: date_compare_datetime
Function.Description:
With this function you can check two dates and times to see which one is the earlier or later than the other.
The function returns -1 if date1 is earlier, 1 if date1 is later and 0 if they are the same.
Function.Parameter: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

Function.Name: date_compare_time
Function.Description:
With this function you can check two dates and times to see which one has the time component earlier or later than the other.
The function returns -1 if datetime1 is earlier, 1 if datetime1 is later and 0 if they are the same, and it ignores the date, so literally just which of the times is further through its given day.
Function.Parameter: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare the first one to.

Function.Name: date_create_datetime
Function.Description: This function will create a datetime value from the components given as the arguments.
Function.Parameter: The year to set.
The month to set.
The day to set.
The hour to set.
The minute to set.
The second to set.

Function.Name: date_current_datetime
Function.Description:
Returns the date-time value of the current moment.
The time returned is based on the default time zone for the system (i.e.: local time).

Function.Name: date_datetime_string
Function.Description: With this function you can create a string containing the given datetime, formatted for the system or device that is running the game when the function is called.
Function.Parameter: The date to use.

Function.Name: date_date_of
Function.Description: Returns the date value of the given datetime.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to extract the date from.

Function.Name: date_date_string
Function.Description: With this function you can create a string containing the given date, formatted as day/month/year.
Function.Parameter: The date to use.

Function.Name: date_days_in_month
Function.Description: With this function you can get the number of days that the given month has, either 28, 29, 30 or 31.
Function.Parameter: The date to use.

Function.Name: date_days_in_year
Function.Description: With this function you can get the number of days that the given year has, returning 365 for a normal year, and 366 for a leap year.
Function.Parameter: The date to use.

Function.Name: date_day_span
Function.Description:
With this function you can get the number of days between two dates.
This value is always positive, and incomplete days will be returned as a fraction.
Function.Parameter: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

Function.Name: date_get_day
Function.Description: This function returns the day (from 1 to 31) of the given datetime.
Function.Parameter: The date to check.

Function.Name: date_get_day_of_year
Function.Description: This function returns the day (from 1 to 366) within the year of the given datetime.
Function.Parameter: The date to check.

Function.Name: date_get_hour
Function.Description: This function returns the hour of the given datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to check.

Function.Name: date_get_hour_of_year
Function.Description: This function returns the hour of the given datetime value within the year (from the total number of hours for the year, taking into account leap years).
Function.Parameter: The datetime to check.

Function.Name: date_get_minute
Function.Description: This function returns the minute of the given datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to check.

Function.Name: date_get_minute_of_year
Function.Description: This function returns the minute of the given datetime value within the year (from the total number of minutes for the year, taking into account leap years).
Function.Parameter: The date to check.

Function.Name: date_get_month
Function.Description: This function returns the month of the given datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to check.

Function.Name: date_get_second
Function.Description: This function returns the second of the given datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to check.

Function.Name: date_get_second_of_year
Function.Description: This function returns the second of the given datetime value within the year (from the total number of seconds for the year, taking into account leap years).
Function.Parameter: The date to check.

Function.Name: date_get_timezone
Function.Description: This function gets the base time zone being used for all the rest of the date and time functions, which can be either local (as set by the system) or UTC.

Function.Name: date_get_week
Function.Description: This function returns the week of the given datetime value within the year.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to check.

Function.Name: date_get_weekday
Function.Description: This function returns the week day value of the given datetime. This will be a value from 0 to 6.
Function.Parameter: The date to check.

Function.Name: date_get_year
Function.Description: This function returns the year of the given datetime.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to check.

Function.Name: date_hour_span
Function.Description:
With this function you can get the number of hours between two dates.
This value is always positive, and incomplete hours will be returned as a fraction.
Function.Parameter: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare the first one to.

Function.Name: date_inc_day
Function.Description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of days, and it will return the new datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to add to.
The number of days (must be an integer) to add.

Function.Name: date_inc_hour
Function.Description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of hours, and it will return the new datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to add to.
The number of hours (must be an integer) to add.

Function.Name: date_inc_minute
Function.Description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of minutes, and it will return the new datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to add to.
The number of minutes (must be an integer) to add.

Function.Name: date_inc_month
Function.Description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of months, and it will return the new datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to add to.
The number of months (must be an integer) to add.

Function.Name: date_inc_second
Function.Description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of seconds, and it will return the new datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to add to.
The number of seconds (must be an integer) to add.

Function.Name: date_inc_week
Function.Description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of weeks, and it will return the new datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to add to.
The number of weeks (must be an integer) to add.

Function.Name: date_inc_year
Function.Description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of years, and it will return the new datetime value.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to add to
The number of years (must be an integer) to add.

Function.Name: date_is_today
Function.Description: This function will return true if the given datetime value is the day it is being checked on (i.e.: today), or false otherwise. This can be a handy function for things like Easter Eggs in your games, or for unlocking seasonal content.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to use.

Function.Name: date_leap_year
Function.Description: This function will return true if the year component of the given datetime value is a leap year or false otherwise. This can be a handy function for things like Easter Eggs in your games, or for unlocking special content.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to use.

Function.Name: date_minute_span
Function.Description: With this function you can get the number of minutes between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete minutes will be returned as a fraction.
Function.Parameter: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

Function.Name: date_month_span
Function.Description: With this function you can get the number of months between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete months will be returned as a fraction.
Function.Parameter: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

Function.Name: date_second_span
Function.Description: With this function you can get the number of seconds between two dates. The return value is always positive and will be a whole number.
Function.Parameter: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

Function.Name: date_set_timezone
Function.Description: This function sets the base time zone to use for all the rest of the date and time functions, which can either be local (as set by the system) or UTC.
Function.Parameter: The time zone to use for the base time.

Function.Name: date_time_of
Function.Description: This function returns the time value of the given datetime.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to extract the time from.

Function.Name: date_time_string
Function.Description: With this function you can create a string containing the given time, formatted for the system or device that is running the game when the function is called.
Function.Parameter: The datetime to use.

Function.Name: date_valid_datetime
Function.Description:
With this function you can check a datetime value to see if it is valid (returns true) or not (returns false).
Note that this function will only consider a valid datetime as being after 1/1/1970 and anything before that will return false.
Function.Parameter: The year to check.
The month to check.
The day to check.
The hour to check.
The minute to check.
The second to check.

Function.Name: date_week_span
Function.Description: With this function you can get the number of weeks between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete weeks will be returned as a fraction.
Function.Parameter: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

Function.Name: date_year_span
Function.Description: With this function you can get the number of years between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete years will be returned as a fraction.
Function.Parameter: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

Function.Name: get_timer
Function.Description: This function returns the time that your game has been running on the chosen platform in microseconds (there are 1 million microseconds per second).

Function.Name: matrix_build
Function.Description: This function creates a custom transformation matrix from 3-dimensional (x, y, z) translation, rotation and scale values and returns it. Or optionally writes the result to an existing matrix that you specify.
Function.Parameter: The x component of the translation vector.
The y component of the translation vector.
The z component of the translation vector.
The angle to rotate around the x-axis (in degrees ).
The angle to rotate around the y-axis (in degrees ).
The angle to rotate around the z-axis (in degrees ).
The x scale amount.
The y scale amount.
The z scale amount.
Optionally you can pass in the matrix in which you would like the result to be stored. This can provide better performance.

Function.Name: matrix_build_identity
Function.Description: This will build a 4x4 identity matrix.

Function.Name: matrix_build_lookat
Function.Description: This function builds a "look-at" (view) matrix. And can optionally write the result to an existing matrix that you specify.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the position to look from.
The y coordinate of the position to look from.
The z coordinate of the position to look from.
The x coordinate of the position to look to.
The y coordinate of the position to look to.
The z coordinate of the position to look to.
The x coordinate of the "up" vector.
The y coordinate of the "up" vector.
The z coordinate of the "up" vector.
Optionally you can pass in the matrix in which you would like the result to be stored. This can provide better performance.

Function.Name: matrix_build_projection_ortho
Function.Description: This function builds an orthographic projection matrix based on the specified parameters (this is the default projection method used when you create a room in GameMaker without changing anything). And can optionally write the result to an existing matrix that you specify.
Function.Parameter: The width of the projection.
The height of the projection.
The near clipping plane.
The far clipping plane.
Optionally you can pass in the matrix in which you would like the result to be stored. This can provide better performance.

Function.Name: matrix_build_projection_perspective
Function.Description: This function builds a perspective projection matrix based on the dimensions of the near clipping plane, using the specified parameters. And can optionally write the result to an existing matrix that you specify.
Function.Parameter: The width of the projection at the near Z position.
The height of the projection at the near Z position.
The near clipping plane.
The far clipping plane.
Optionally you can pass in the matrix in which you would like the result to be stored. This can provide better performance.

Function.Name: matrix_build_projection_perspective_fov
Function.Description: This function builds a perspective projection matrix matrix based on field of view, using the specified parameters. And can optionally write the result to an existing matrix that you specify.
Function.Parameter: The vertical angle of the field of view.
The aspect ratio of the field of view.
The near clipping plane.
The far clipping plane.
Optionally you can pass in the matrix in which you would like the result to be stored. This can provide better performance.

Function.Name: matrix_get
Function.Description: This function gets the currently used matrix of the given type, which can be either the world, view or projection matrix. And can optionally write the result to an existing matrix that you specify.
Function.Parameter: The type of matrix to get the values of
Optionally you can pass in the matrix in which you would like the result to be stored. This can provide better performance.

Function.Name: matrix_multiply
Function.Description: This function multiplies two matrices together to create a new matrix and returns the result as a new matrix, or optionally writes the result to an existing matrix that you specify.
Function.Parameter: The first matrix index to use.
The second matrix index to use.
Optionally you can pass in the matrix in which you would like the result to be stored. This can provide better performance.

Function.Name: matrix_inverse
Function.Description: This function returns a new matrix that is the inverse of the matrix you pass it, or optionally writes the result to an existing matrix that you specify.
Function.Parameter: The matrix to get the inverse of.
Optionally you can pass in the matrix in which you would like the result to be stored. This can provide better performance.

Function.Name: matrix_set
Function.Description: This function sets the current matrix of the given type (world, view or projection) to the given matrix.
Function.Parameter: The type of matrix to get the values of
The matrix data as an array

Function.Name: matrix_stack_clear
Function.Description: This function clears the matrix stack.

Function.Name: matrix_stack_is_empty
Function.Description: This function can be used to check whether the matrix stack is empty (returns true) or not (returns false).

Function.Name: matrix_stack_pop
Function.Description: This function removes the matrix that is at the top of the current matrix stack.

Function.Name: matrix_stack_push
Function.Description: This function multiplies the given matrix with the matrix currently at the top of the matrix stack and pushes the resulting matrix onto the stack.
Function.Parameter: The matrix to push to the stack.

Function.Name: matrix_stack_set
Function.Description: This function overwrites the current top of the matrix stack with the specified matrix.
Function.Parameter: The matrix index to use.

Function.Name: matrix_stack_top
Function.Description: This function returns the current top matrix of the stack, but does not remove it (for that use matrix_stack_pop()).

Function.Name: matrix_transform_vertex
Function.Description: This function transforms a vector by a matrix and returns the result as a new array, or optionally writes the result to an existing array that you specify. * array[0] = x * array[1] = y * array[2] = z * array[3] = w (if x, y, z and w are provided).
Function.Parameter: The matrix to use
The x component of the transform vector
The y component of the transform vector
The z component of the transform vector
The w component of the transform vector
Optionally you can pass in the array in which you would like the result to be stored. This can provide better performance.

Function.Name: abs
Function.Description: This function returns the absolute value of the input argument, so if it's a positive value then it will remain the same, but if it's negative it will be multiplied by -1 to make it positive.
Function.Parameter: The number to turn absolute.

Function.Name: ceil
