Function.Description: This function takes any real number and rounds it up to the nearest integer.
Function.Parameter: The number to change.

Function.Name: choose
Function.Description: This function chooses a random value from the arguments you pass it.
Function.Parameter: An input value that can be string, integer, variable or constant.
An input value that can be string, integer, variable or constant.

Function.Name: clamp
Function.Description: With this function you can maintain an input value between a specified range.
Function.Parameter: The value to clamp.
The minimum value to clamp between.
The maximum value to clamp between.

Function.Name: exp
Function.Description: This is the function power(e, n), where e is approximately 2.718281828 (also known as Euler's Number), and n is the number of times it should be multiplied by itself.
Function.Parameter: The power of e.

Function.Name: floor
Function.Description: This function takes any real number and rounds it down to the nearest integer.
Function.Parameter: The number to floor.

Function.Name: frac
Function.Description: This function returns the fractional part of n, that is, the part behind the decimal dot.
Function.Parameter: The number to change.

Function.Name: irandom
Function.Description: This function returns a random integer (whole number) value.
Function.Parameter: The upper range from which the random number will be selected.

Function.Name: irandom_range
Function.Description: This function returns a random integer value within the given range (both inclusive).
Function.Parameter: The low end of the range from which the random number will be selected.
The high end of the range from which the random number will be selected.

Function.Name: lerp
Function.Description: With this function you can find the value that equates to the position between two other values for a given percentage.
Function.Parameter: The first value.
The second value.
The amount to interpolate.

Function.Name: ln
Function.Description: This function returns the natural logarithm of the given value.
Function.Parameter: The input value.

Function.Name: log10
Function.Description: This function returns the logarithm base 10 of the given number, which is the number of 10's that you need to multiply together to get n.
Function.Parameter: The input value.

Function.Name: log2
Function.Description: This function returns the logarithm base 2 of the given number, which is the number of 2's that you need to multiply together to get n.
Function.Parameter: The input value.

Function.Name: logn
Function.Description: This function returns the logarithm base n of the given number, which is the number of times that you need to multiply n by itself to get the value.
Function.Parameter: The log base.
The input value.

Function.Name: math_get_epsilon
Function.Description: This function will return the current epsilon value for the target platform.

Function.Name: math_set_epsilon
Function.Description: This function sets the epsilon value for number comparisons, which is used to determine whether two numbers subject to rounding errors are close enough to be considered "equal".
Function.Parameter: The new epsilon value (from 0 to 0.999999999).

Function.Name: max
Function.Description: This function returns the maximum of the input values, of which it can have as many as you require (note that more arguments will mean that the function will be slower to parse).
Function.Parameter: The first value to compare.
The following values.

Function.Name: mean
Function.Description: This function works by adding up all the input values and then dividing them by their own number.
Function.Parameter: The first value to use in computation.
The following values.

Function.Name: median
Function.Description: This function returns the median of the input values, that is, the middle value, or the larger of the two middle values when the number of arguments is even.
Function.Parameter: The first value to use in computation.
The following values.

Function.Name: min
Function.Description: This function returns the minimum of the input values, of which it can have as many as you require (note that more arguments will mean that the function will be slower to parse).
Function.Parameter: The first value to compare.
The following values.

Function.Name: power
Function.Description: This will return the value of a number multiplied by itself "n" number of times.
Function.Parameter: The number to change.
How many times to multiply x by itself.

Function.Name: random
Function.Description: This function returns a random floating-point (decimal) number between 0.0 (inclusive) and the specified upper limit (inclusive).
Function.Parameter: The upper range from which the random number will be selected.

Function.Name: randomise
Function.Description: This function sets the seed to a random value. Should you need to keep a consistent value over a number of runs of a game, however, you should be using random_set_seed() instead.

Function.Name: random_get_seed
Function.Description: This function retrieves the seed used by GameMaker to generate random numbers.

Function.Name: random_range
Function.Description: This function returns a random floating-point (decimal) number between the specified lower limit (inclusive) and the specified upper limit (inclusive).
Function.Parameter: The low end of the range from which the random number will be selected.
The high end of the range from which the random number will be selected.

Function.Name: random_set_seed
Function.Description: This function sets the seed used by GameMaker to generate random numbers.
Function.Parameter: The seed to set.

Function.Name: round
Function.Description: This function takes a real number and rounds it up or down to the nearest integer.
Function.Parameter: The number to round.

Function.Name: sign
Function.Description: This function returns whether a number is positive, negative or neither and returns 1, -1, 0 respectively.
Function.Parameter: The number to get the sign of.

Function.Name: sqr
Function.Description: Multiplies a number by itself and so returns the square of that number.
Function.Parameter: The number to square.

Function.Name: sqrt
Function.Description: This function returns the square root of the given number.
Function.Parameter: The number to get the square root of.

Function.Name: collision_circle
Function.Description: This function checks a circular zone around a point for a collision with the given instance(s), instances of the given object and/or tile maps, and returns the first result found.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the center of the circle to check.
The y coordinate of the center of the circle to check.
The radius (distance in pixels from its center to its edge).
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on pixel-perfect collisions (true = slow) or its bounding box in general (false = fast).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: collision_circle_list
Function.Description: This function checks a circular zone around a point for a collision with the given instance(s), instances of the given object and/or tile maps. It returns the number of results found and adds them to the given DS list.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the center of the circle to check.
The y coordinate of the center of the circle to check.
The radius (distance in pixels from its center to its edge).
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).
The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.
Whether the list should be ordered by distance (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: collision_ellipse
Function.Description: This function checks an elliptical zone around a point for a collision with the given instance(s), instances of the given object and/or tile maps, and returns the first result found.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left side of the ellipse to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the ellipse to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the ellipse to check.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the ellipse to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: collision_ellipse_list
Function.Description: This function checks an elliptical zone around a point for a collision with the given instance(s), instances of the given object and/or tile maps. It returns the number of results found and adds them to the given DS list. It returns the number of results found and adds them to the given DS list.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left side of the ellipse to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the ellipse to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the ellipse to check.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the ellipse to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).
The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.
Whether the list should be ordered by distance (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: collision_line
Function.Description: This function checks along a line for a collision with the given instance(s), instances of the given object and/or tile maps, and returns the first result found.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line.
The y coordinate of the end of the line.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: collision_line_list
Function.Description: This function checks along a line for a collision with the given instance(s), instances of the given object and/or tile maps. It returns the number of results found and adds them to the given DS list.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line.
The y coordinate of the end of the line.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).
The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.
Whether the list should be ordered by distance (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: collision_point
Function.Description: This function checks a point for a collision with the given instance(s), instances of the given object and/or tile maps, and returns the first result found.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the point to check.
The y coordinate of the point to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: collision_point_list
Function.Description: This function checks a point for a collision with the given instance(s), instances of the given object and/or tile maps. It returns the number of results found and adds them to the given DS list.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the point to check.
The y coordinate of the point to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).
The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.
Whether the list should be ordered by distance (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: collision_rectangle
Function.Description: This function checks a rectangular area for a collision with the given instance(s), instances of the given object and/or tile maps, and returns the first result found.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: collision_rectangle_list
Function.Description: This function checks a rectangular area for a collision with the given instance(s), instances of the given object and/or tile maps. It returns the number of results found and adds them to the given DS list.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).
The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.
Whether the list should be ordered by distance (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: place_empty
Function.Description: You can use this function to check and see if the calling instance would collide with any other instance of an object or all instances in your game. For this collision to resolve correctly, the instance running the code must have a valid collision mask (either for the sprite itself, or through the mask_index) and it will only register collisions with those instances that also have a valid mask.
Function.Parameter: The x position to check.
The y position to check.
Optional! The object to check against.

Function.Name: place_free
Function.Description: You can use this function to check and see if the calling instance would collide with any instance flagged as solid in your game.
Function.Parameter: The x position to check.
The y position to check.

Function.Name: place_meeting
Function.Description: With this function you can check a position for a collision with another instance or all instances of an object using the collision mask of the instance that runs the code.
Function.Parameter: The x position to check.
The y position to check.
The instance or object to check for.

Function.Name: point_in_circle
Function.Description: This function checks if the given point falls within the given circular area.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the point to check.
The y coordinate of the point to check.
The x coordinate of the circle centre.
The y coordinate of the circle centre.
The radius of the circle.

Function.Name: point_in_rectangle
Function.Description: This function checks if the given point falls within the given rectangular area.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the point to check.
The y coordinate of the point to check.
The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.

Function.Name: point_in_triangle
Function.Description: This function checks if the given point falls within the given triangular area.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the point to check.
The y coordinate of the point to check.
The x coordinate of the first corner of the triangle to check.
The y coordinate of the first corner of the triangle to check.
The x coordinate of the second corner of the triangle to check.
The y coordinate of the second corner of the triangle to check.
The x coordinate of the third corner of the triangle to check.
The y coordinate of the third corner of the triangle to check.

Function.Name: position_change
Function.Description: This function will check a position for a collision with any instances at the given point, and if there is one, it will change all instances in collision to be instances of the chosen object.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of where to change colliding instances.
The y coordinate of where to change colliding instances.
The new object the calling object will change into.
Whether to perform that new object's Create event (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: position_destroy
Function.Description:
This function simply destroys all instances that are found to be in collision with the specified position.
Collisions are based on the mask of the instances, and if any part of the mask overlaps with the target point it then the function will destroy that instance.
Instances destroyed in this way will trigger their Destroy and Clean Up events.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of where to destroy colliding instances.
The y coordinate of where to destroy colliding instances.

Function.Name: position_empty
Function.Description: This function will check to see if a given position enters into collision with any instance with a valid collision mask at the given position.
Function.Parameter: The x position to check.
The y position to check.

Function.Name: position_meeting
Function.Description:
With this function you can check a position for a collision with another instance or all instances of an object.
When you use this you are checking a single point in the room for an instance or an object.
The check will be done against the bounding box of the instance or against the mask of the instance if that instance has precise collisions checked.
Function.Parameter: The x position to check.
The y position to check.
The object (or instance id, or the keywords "all" or "other") to check for a collision with.

Function.Name: rectangle_in_circle
Function.Description: This function will check a rectangular area that you define to see if it is either not in collision, completely within the destination bounds, or if it is simply touching, a defined circular area. If they are not touching at all the function will return 0, if the source is completely within the destination it will return 1, and if they are simply overlapping then it will return 2.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left side of the source rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top side of the source rectangle.
The x coordinate of the right side of the source rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the source rectangle.
The x coordinate of the centre of the circle
The y coordinate of the centre of the circle.
The radius around the center point in which to check for a collision.

Function.Name: rectangle_in_rectangle
Function.Description: This function will check two rectangular areas that you define to see if the source rectangle is either not in collision, completely within the destination rectangles bounds, or if they are simply touching. If they are not touching at all the function will return 0, if the source is completely within the destination it will return 1, and if they are simply overlapping then it will return 2.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left side of the source rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top side of the source rectangle.
The x coordinate of the right side of the source rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the source rectangle.
The x coordinate of the left side of the destination rectangle to check against.
The y coordinate of the top side of the destination rectangle to check against.
The x coordinate of the right side of the destination rectangle to check against.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the destination rectangle to check against.

Function.Name: rectangle_in_triangle
Function.Description: This function will check a rectangular area that you define to see if it is either not in collision, completely within the destination bounds, or if it is simply touching, a defined triangular area. If they are not touching at all the function will return 0, if the source is completely within the destination it will return 1, and if they are simply overlapping then it will return 2.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left side of the source rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top side of the source rectangle.
The x coordinate of the right side of the source rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the source rectangle.
The x coordinate of the first side of the triangle to check.
The y coordinate of the first side of the triangle to check.
The x coordinate of the second side of the triangle to check.
The y coordinate of the second side of the triangle to check.
The x coordinate of the third side of the triangle to check.
The y coordinate of the third side of the triangle to check.

Function.Name: mp_grid_add_cell
Function.Description: This function marks an individual cell within the given MP grid as "forbidden" meaning that the path finding functions will not ever cross it.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be used
Horizontal position of the cell in the grid
Vertical position of the cell in the grid

Function.Name: mp_grid_add_instances
Function.Description: This function uses the instance collision mask (decided by the sprite properties or the mask index of the calling instance) to mark cells as forbidden or not in an MP grid, where forbidden cells cannot be crossed by any of the pathfinding functions. You can specify in the function whether to consider precise collisions or not and the forbidden cells marked will change depending on this setting.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be used
Object index, or instance id, of the instances to be added into the MP grid
Whether the check is based on pixel-perfect collisions (true = slow) or its bounding box in general (false = fast).

Function.Name: mp_grid_add_rectangle
Function.Description: This function takes a rectangle in room coordinates and marks all MP grid cells that "touch" that rectangle as forbidden, meaning that the pathfinding functions cannot cross them.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be used
The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.
The x coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.

Function.Name: mp_grid_clear_all
Function.Description: This function clears an MP grid of all "forbidden" cells.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be used

Function.Name: mp_grid_clear_cell
Function.Description: This function clears a specific "cell" of an MP grid. Cells are not calculated as room coordinates, but rather as grid coordinates, where (0, 0) is the top-left corner of the grid.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be used
Horizontal position of the cell to clear
vertical position of the cell to clear

Function.Name: mp_grid_clear_rectangle
Function.Description: With this function you can define an area in room coordinates which will then clear the corresponding cells in the specified MP grid. Even if a cell partially falls within the defined rectangular region it will be cleared.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be used
The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.
The x coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.

Function.Name: mp_grid_create
Function.Description: This function creates an MP grid for the motion planning functions.
Function.Parameter: Starting x coordinate of the MP grid in the room
Starting y coordinate of the MP grid in the room
Number of horizontal cells that the MP grid will contain
Number of vertical cells that the MP grid will contain
The width (in pixels) of each individual cell of the MP grid
The height (in pixels) of each individual cell of the MP grid

Function.Name: mp_grid_destroy
Function.Description: This function destroys the given MP grid and frees up the memory used by it.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be destroyed

Function.Name: mp_grid_draw
Function.Description: This function draws the specified MP grid, marking free cells as green and forbidden cells as red.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be drawn

Function.Name: mp_grid_get_cell
Function.Description: This function returns whether the given MP grid cell is flagged as occupied or not. If it has been occupied or the position being checked is out of the grid's bounds, the function will return -1, otherwise it will return 0.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be used
The x coordinate of the grid to check.
The y coordinate of the grid to check.

Function.Name: mp_grid_path
Function.Description: This function creates a path that will navigate through the given MP grid from a start point to a finish point, avoiding any obstacles that have been added into the grid.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be used
index of the path that is to be used by the function
Starting x coordinate of the new path
Starting y coordinate of the new path
Finishing x coordinate of the new path
Finishing y coordinate of the new path
Indicates whether diagonal moves are allowed instead of just horizontal or vertical

Function.Name: mp_grid_to_ds_grid
Function.Description: This function copies the given MP grid into a DS grid. A cell in the DS grid will contain the value -1 if it's flagged as occupied in the MP grid, or 0 if it isn't.
Function.Parameter: Index of the MP grid that is to be used
Index of the DS grid that is to be used to copy the grid data to.

Function.Name: mp_linear_path
Function.Description: This function computes a straight line path from the current instance position to the given target position. The path may be blocked by all instances or just solid ones.
Function.Parameter: The index of the path to be used.
The target x position.
The target y position.
The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.
Whether to check for collisions with all instances (true) or just solid ones (false).

Function.Name: mp_linear_path_object
Function.Description: This function computes a straight line path from the current instance position to the given target position. The path may be blocked by instances of a given object, by a single instance or by all instances.
Function.Parameter: The index of the path to be used
The target x position.
The target y position.
The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.
The object that is to block the path. Can be an object index, an instance id or the special keyword ,all

Function.Name: mp_linear_step
Function.Description: With this function you tell an instance to take a "step" towards the given target position. The instance may stop at a collision with all instances or just solid ones.
Function.Parameter: The target x position.
The target y position.
The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.
Whether to check all instances (true) or just solid ones (false).

Function.Name: mp_linear_step_object
Function.Description: With this function you tell an instance to take a "step" towards the given target position. The instance may stop at a collision with instances of a given object, with a single instance or with all instances.
Function.Parameter: The target x position.
The target y position.
The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.
The object that is to block the path. Can be an object index, an instance id or the special keyword, all

Function.Name: mp_potential_path
Function.Description: This function computes a path for the instance from its current position and orientation to the position specified by the xgoal,ygoal arguments.
Function.Parameter: index of the path that is to be used by the function
The target x position.
The target y position.
The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.
This number is used to prevent an infinite loop. It should be larger than 1. See the function description for more information.
Whether to check all instances (true) or just solid ones (false).

Function.Name: mp_potential_path_object
Function.Description: This function computes a path for the instance from its current position and orientation to the position specified by the xgoal, ygoal arguments.
Function.Parameter: index of the path that is to be used by the function
The target x position.
The target y position.
The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.
This number is used to prevent an infinite loop. It should be larger than 1. See the function description for more information.
The object that is to block the path. Can be an object index, an instance id or the special keyword ,all

Function.Name: mp_potential_settings
Function.Description: The mp_potential_* functions do their work using a number of parameters that can be changed using this function.
Function.Parameter: The number of degrees either side of the current direction that the instance can rotate in a step
The number of degrees either side of the current direction that the instance can check for a collision
The number of steps ahead that the instance can check for a collision. Larger values are slower than lower ones.
Use this to allow the instance to rotate on the spot when no path is found (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: mp_potential_step
Function.Description: This function lets the instance take a step towards a particular position defined by xgoal/ygoal, all the while trying to avoid obstacles.
Function.Parameter: The target x position.
The target y position.
The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.
Whether to check all instances (true) or just solid ones (false).

Function.Name: mp_potential_step_object
Function.Description: This function lets the instance take a step towards a particular position defined by xgoal/ygoal, all the while trying to avoid obstacles.
Function.Parameter: The target x position.
The target y position.
The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.
The object that is to block the path of the instance running the function. Can be an object index, an instance id or the special keyword ,all.

Function.Name: motion_add
Function.Description: This function will modify the current direction and speed of the instance running the code, combining the values given with the current values. If you wish to simply change these values, you should be using the function motion_set().
Function.Parameter: The added direction.
The added speed.

Function.Name: motion_set
Function.Description: This function sets a new direction of movement and a new speed to the instance running the code. Note that this does not add to the instance's current speed and direction (for that you would use motion_add()) but rather forces it to the new settings.
Function.Parameter: The new direction.
The new speed.`

Function.Name: move_bounce_all
Function.Description: With this function you can command an instance to bounce off all instances within the room, with the only exception being those that have no sprite or mask index assigned to them. You can also tell it to use precise collision checking when enabled, but be aware that this requires all instances to have precise masks enabled and will greatly slow down your game when many instances are involved due to the amount of processing that has to be done.
Function.Parameter: Whether to enable advanced bouncing (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: move_bounce_solid
Function.Description: With this function you can command an instance to bounce off only those instances marked as solid within the room. You can also tell it to use precise collision checking when enabled, but be aware that this requires all instances to have precise masks enabled and will greatly slow down your game when many instances are involved due to the amount of processing that has to be done.
Function.Parameter: Whether to enable advanced bouncing (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: move_contact_all
Function.Description: This function will move the instance running the code a set number of pixels in the specified direction until it meets any other instance with a valid mask. You can use -1 or 0 for the maxdist being a default 1000px, i.e.: GameMaker will move the instance continually up 1000 pixels until it is out of collision.
Function.Parameter: The direction to move in.
The maximum distance the object can travel (-1 or 0 a default value of 1000 pixels).

Function.Name: move_contact_solid
Function.Description: This function will move the instance running the code a set number of pixels in the specified direction until it meets an instance with solid flagged as true. You can use -1 or 0 for the maxdist being a default 1000px, i.e.: GameMaker will move the instance continually up 1000 pixels until it is out of collision.
Function.Parameter: The direction to move in.
The maximum distance the object can travel (-1 or 0 a default value of 1000 pixels).

Function.Name: move_outside_all
Function.Description: With this function you can tell an instance to move out of a collision in any direction and any number of pixels each step, with a value of -1 or 0 for the maxdist being a default 1000px, i.e.: GameMaker will move the instance continually up 1000 pixels until it is out of collision.
Function.Parameter: The direction to move in.
The maximum distance the object can travel (-1 or 0 a default value of 1000 pixels).

Function.Name: move_and_collide
Function.Description: With this function you can tell an instance to move in a direction, resolving collisions on the way and specify a direction in which the instance will attempt to move to get past obstacles, thus allowing traversal of slopes or small steps. Returns an array of instances that it has collided with.
Function.Parameter: The x component of direction to move in.
The y component of direction to move in.
The object to check for collisions with.
The number of steps the motion will be broken down into to resolve collisions, defaults to 4
The x component of direction to move to attempt to avoid obstacles. If not specified the perpendicular to the direction of movement is used.
The y component of direction to move to attempt to avoid obstacles. If not specified the perpendicular to the direction of movement is used.
The maximum distance in the x direction the instance will move. If less than or equal to 0 no clamping is performed.
The maximum distance in the y direction the instance will move. If less than or equal to 0 no clamping is performed.

Function.Name: move_outside_solid
Function.Description: With this function you can tell an instance to move out of a collision with any instance flagged as solid in any direction and any number of pixels each step, with a value of -1 or 0 for the maxdist being a default 1000px, i.e.: GameMaker will move the instance continually up 1000 pixels until it is out of collision.
Function.Parameter: The direction to move in.
The maximum distance the object can travel (-1 or 0 a default value of 1000 pixels).

Function.Name: move_random
Function.Description: With this function you can set the instance to a position anywhere in the room, but aligned to an "invisible" grid. So a value of 32 for the hsnap and vsnap will set the instance to a random position that is aligned to a grid of 32x32 squares (you can set these values to 1 to get a position anywhere in the room).
Function.Parameter: The horizontal snapping (the size in pixels between "cells").
The vertical snapping (the size in pixels between "cells").

Function.Name: move_snap
Function.Description: This function is used to "snap" the instance to a grid of a given size. The instance will be snapped to the nearest corresponding position on the "invisible" grid that the hsnap and vsnap values define.
Function.Parameter: The horizontal snapping (the size in pixels between "cells").
The vertical snapping (the size in pixels between "cells").

Function.Name: move_towards_point
Function.Description: This function tells the instance running the code to move towards a set point at a set speed.
Function.Parameter: The x position of the point to move towards.
The y position of the point to move towards.
The speed to move at in pixels per step.

Function.Name: move_wrap
Function.Description: This function will automatically "wrap" an instance that has left the room on either the horizontal or vertical (or both) axis. You can specify a margin outside the edges of the room for this to occur, and when the instance has travelled outside of that margin GameMaker will automatically wrap it back into the room at the other side.
Function.Parameter: Whether to wrap horizontally (true) or not (false).
Whether to wrap vertically (true) or not (false).
How far outside the room, in pixels, the object must be to initiate wrapping.

Function.Name: place_snapped
Function.Description: With this function you can check and see if the origin of an instance (its (x and y position) is aligned to a grid with the hsnap and vsnap values specified by you.
Function.Parameter: The horizontal snapping to check.
The vertical snapping to check.

Function.Name: network_connect
Function.Description:
With this function you can send a request to connect to a server. The function takes the socket id to connect through and requires you to give the IP address to connect to as well as the port to connect through, and if the connection fails a value of less than 0 will be returned.
This connection uses a special protocol that ensures only GameMaker games connect to each other, however if you need to connect to a server that is not a GameMaker game, you can use network_connect_raw().
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to use.
The URL or IP to connect to.
The port to connect to.

Function.Name: network_connect_async
Function.Description:
With this function you can send a request to connect to a server. The function takes the socket id to connect through and requires you to give the IP address to connect to as well as the port to connect through, and if the connection fails a value of less than 0 will be returned.
The connection uses a special protocol that ensures only GameMaker games connect to each other, however if you need to connect to a server that is not a GameMaker game, you can use network_connect_async_raw().
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to use.
The URL or IP to connect to.
The port to connect to.

Function.Name: network_connect_raw
Function.Description: With this function you can send a request to connect to a server. The function takes the socket id to connect through and requires you to give the IP address to connect to as well as the port to connect through, and if the connection fails a value of less than 0 will be returned.
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to use.
The URL or IP to connect to.
The port to connect to.

Function.Name: network_connect_raw_async
Function.Description: With this function you can send a request to connect to a server. The function takes the socket id to connect through and requires you to give the IP address to connect to as well as the port to connect through, and if the connection fails a value of less than 0 will be returned.
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to use.
The URL or IP to connect to.
The port to connect to.

Function.Name: network_create_server
Function.Description: This function is used to create a new network server for your game, using one of the permitted connection protocols.
Function.Parameter: The type of server to create.
The port that the server will use.
The maximum number of clients that can connect at once.

Function.Name: network_create_server_raw
Function.Description: This function is used to create a new raw network server for your game, using one of the permitted connection protocols.
Function.Parameter: The type of server to create.
The port that the server will use.
The maximum number of clients that can connect at once.

Function.Name: network_create_socket
Function.Description: This function creates a new client socket for your game to communicate over the network. The function returns a unique id for the socket, or a value of less than 0 if the connection fails.
Function.Parameter: The type of socket connection to create.

Function.Name: network_create_socket_ext
Function.Description: This function creates a new client socket for your game to communicate over the network. The function returns a unique id for the socket, or a value of less than 0 if the connection fails.
Function.Parameter: The type of socket connection to create.
The port to use

Function.Name: network_destroy
Function.Description: With this function you can remove a network socket connection from your game.
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to remove.

Function.Name: network_resolve
Function.Description: This function will return the IP address of the given URL.
Function.Parameter: The URL to get the IP of.

Function.Name: network_send_broadcast
Function.Description: With this function you can broadcast the data from a buffer locally to a range of IP addresses. The function will return the number of bytes of data sent, or a number less than 0 if the send has failed.
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to use.
The port that the server will use.
The id of the buffer to get the data from.
The size (in bytes) of the data.

Function.Name: network_send_packet
Function.Description:
With this function you can send a data "packet" through the network. The function will return the number of bytes of data sent, or a number less than 0 if the send has failed.
Note that the final size of the data being sent by this function will also include the GameMaker header information, which is an additional 12 bytes.
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to use.
The id of the buffer to get the data from.
The size (in bytes) of the data.

Function.Name: network_send_raw
Function.Description:
With this function you can send a "raw" data packet through the network. The function will return the number of bytes of data sent, or a number less than 0 if the send has failed.
Note that the data is sent "raw", i.e. it is not formatted by GameMaker in any way.
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to use.
The id of the buffer to get the data from.
The size (in bytes) of the data.
Optional flags to affect how the data is sent.

Function.Name: network_send_udp
Function.Description:
With this function you can send data over the network using UDP to a server. The function will return the number of bytes of data sent, or a number less than 0 if the send has failed.
Note that the final size of the data being sent by this function will also include the GameMaker header information, which is an additional 12 bytes.
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to use.
The url or IP to connect to.
The port to connect to.
The id of the buffer to get the data from.
The size (in bytes) of the data.

Function.Name: network_send_udp_raw
Function.Description:
With this function you can send data over the network using UDP to a server. The function will return the number of bytes of data sent, or a number less than 0 if the send has failed.
Note that the data is sent "raw", i.e. it is not formatted by GameMaker in any way.
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to use.
The url or IP to connect to.
The port to connect to.
The id of the buffer to get the data from.
The size (in bytes) of the data.

Function.Name: network_set_config
Function.Description: With this function you can set different network configurations.
Function.Parameter: The config constant to set (refer to the table at the top of this page).
The setting of the config value.
The setting of the config value.

Function.Name: network_set_timeout
Function.Description:
With this function you can set the timeout for reading and writing data to/from a server through the given socket.
Note that the timeout does not generate any type of event, so you will need to deal with timeouts yourself using alarms (for example).
Function.Parameter: The id of the socket to use.
The milliseconds in which a transfer from a server will timeout.
The milliseconds in which a transfer to a server will timeout.

Function.Name: environment_get_variable
Function.Description: This function returns the value of the environment variable with the given name.
Function.Parameter: The name of the environment variable to check

Function.Name: external_call
Function.Description: If you have created an external function call to a dll or dylib using external_define(), you can use this function to then call it. You supply the name of the previously defined function as well as each of the arguments it requires (each argument must be of the correct type, either real or string) and the function returns the result of the external call.
Function.Parameter: The name of the function that you want to call
The different arguments that you want to pass through to the external function

Function.Name: external_define
Function.Description: This function can be used to define an external function call to a specific dll (for Windows) or dylib (for Mac). This file can be either an included file or part of an extension.
Function.Parameter: The name of the dll file (string)
The name of the function (string)
The calling convention used
The type of the result to expect
The number of arguments (0 - 10)
The different types of arguments being used

Function.Name: external_free
Function.Description: This function frees the memory associated with the dll or dylib with the given name.
Function.Parameter: The name of the dll or dylib that you want to free

Function.Name: gml_pragma
Function.Description: This function affects how the given target compiles your code and should be called with the different commands to further optimise the final compilation of your project. These commands are effectively pre-processed before the game is compiled and so the function can be placed anywhere in your project and it will still be processed before the game is fully compiled.
Function.Parameter: A string with one of the supported commands.
Optional argument or arguments for the given command.

Function.Name: gml_release_mode
Function.Description: This function sets whether the game is running in release mode. Enabling release mode will disable certain internal error checks at runtime.
Function.Parameter: Either true to set release mode or false for general development.

Function.Name: os_check_permission
Function.Description:
With this function you can check to see if a specific permission has been granted to the game by the user. The function returns one of os_permission_granted, os_permission_denied, os_permission_denied_dont_request.
See Android documentation for the permissions that can be requested.
Function.Parameter: The permission to request

Function.Name: os_get_config
Function.Description: This function returns the name (as a string) of the currently selected configuration for your game.

Function.Name: os_get_info
Function.Description: This function returns a DS Map with detailed information about the OS that the game is running on. The exact information returned will depend on the OS and the device.

Function.Name: os_get_language
Function.Description: This function returns a string with the two letter Language Code for the OS that is running the game, as set by the ISO639 standard. If the information is not available, the function will return an empty string "", or "en" for "English" language.

Function.Name: os_get_region
Function.Description: This function returns a string with the two or three letter Regional Code for the OS that is running the game, as set by the ISO3166-1 standard. If the information is not available, it will hold simply an empty string "".

Function.Name: os_is_network_connected
Function.Description: With this function you can check if your device currently has an internet connection. Depending on the value of the attempt_connection argument and the OS, it may attempt to make a connection before returning a value.
Function.Parameter: OPTIONAL! Set this parameter to a value other than network_connect_none to attempt an OS level connection when called.

Function.Name: os_is_paused
Function.Description: You can use this function to check if the device the game is running on is paused or not.

Function.Name: os_lock_orientation
Function.Description:
With this function you can "lock" your device to the current orientation until such time as you "free" it to allow all Game Options enabled orientations again for that target platform.
Note that you likely want to confirm the orientation is as desired before locking.
Function.Parameter: Set to true or false to enable or disable orientation locking.

Function.Name: os_set_orientation_lock
Function.Description:
With this function you can "lock" your device to the current orientation until such time as you "free" it to allow all Game Options enabled orientations again for that target platform.
Note that you likely want to confirm the orientation is as desired before locking.
Function.Parameter: true if landscape orientation is allowed, false otherwise
true if portait orientation is allowed, false otherwise

Function.Name: os_powersave_enable
Function.Description: With this function you can turn on or off the power saving features of the device. This is important as certain games (for example those that use the tilt functions) may not generate events that the OS can interpret as being user input and so shut down the screen or exit the game. By setting this function to false you can disable the power saving features and ensure that the screen (and game) are always functioning.
Function.Parameter: Set to true or false to enable or disable powersave functions.

Function.Name: parameter_count
Function.Description:
This function returns the number of command-line parameters passed to the game.
Note that this function works on the HTML5 platform, retrieving the URL parameters.

Function.Name: parameter_string
Function.Description:
This function returns the value of the command-line parameter at the given position.
Note that this function works on the HTML5 platform, retrieving the URL parameters.

Function.Name: scheduler_resolution_get
Function.Description: This function is used to retrieve the resolution of the Windows thread scheduler in milliseconds. If the scheduler's resolution is set to the default value (as set by Windows), the function will return -1.

Function.Name: scheduler_resolution_set
Function.Description: This function is used to change the resolution of the Windows thread scheduler. The resolution value supplied in the argument needs to be in milliseconds.
Function.Parameter: The new resolution value (in milliseconds) or -1 for default

Function.Name: physics_debug
Function.Description: This function is used to toggle physics debug messages and errors.
Function.Parameter: Enable or Disable errors and messages

Function.Name: physics_raycast
Function.Description: This function checks the physics fixtures of the objects given against the ray specified, it will return an array of structures that will give the hitPointX, hitPointY (the room coordinates of the intersection), normalX, normalY (the normal of the intersection), fraction (the normalised distance down the ray of the intersection)
Function.Parameter: x position of the start of the ray.
y position of the start of the ray.
x position of the start of the ray.
y position of the start of the ray.
instance or object id (or an array of instance or object ids) to check the ray against, these should have physics fixtures
set to true if you want all hits returned, false if you want the closest hit only - defaults to false
proportion of the ray to check, defaults to 1.0, can be set to be smaller or larger

Function.Name: physics_mass_properties
Function.Description: This function can be used to set custom mass and inertia values for a physics-enabled instance. Note that the mass is calculated in real world weight (i.e.:kilograms) and you should always try and keep values realistic for what you are modelling.
Function.Parameter: The new mass that you want the fixture to have.
The local x coordinate of the new center of mass.
The local y coordinate of the new center of mass.
Set the inertia for the fixture.

Function.Name: physics_test_overlap
Function.Description: This function can be used to check if the physical body of the calling instance (i.e. any of its bound fixtures) overlaps, or will overlap, when rotated and placed at a given position in the room.
Function.Parameter: The x position in the room to check
The y position in the room to check
The angle to check (of the calling instance)
The object index or instance ID to check for, or one of the keywords all or other

Function.Name: physics_fixture_add_point
Function.Description: This function defines the points of a polygon which has previously been set to the fixture using either physics_fixture_set_polygon_shape() or it can be used to add points to a chain of edge fixtures using the function physics_fixture_set_chain_shape(). Note that for a polygon shape, the points are relative to the origin of the fixture, with the (0, 0) position of the x/y axis being the centre, and the subsequent coordinates being calculated as usual in GameMaker with down/right being +x,+y and up/left being -x,-y.
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture
the x position of the point (relative to the fixture origin for polygon shapes)
the y position of the point (relative to the fixture origin for polygon shapes)

Function.Name: physics_fixture_bind
Function.Description: This function binds the given fixture to the given target object or instance and returns the ID of the bound fixture.
Function.Parameter: the fixture that is to be bound
the target instance that is to receive the fixture (can be an instance id, an object id, other, or all)

Function.Name: physics_fixture_bind_ext
Function.Description: This function binds the given fixture to the given target object or instance at an offset and returns the ID of the bound fixture. Note that a fixture can only support a single offset, as adding multiple offsets to a single fixture is not supported by Box2D.
Function.Parameter: the fixture that is to be bound
the target instance that is to receive the fixture (can be an instance id, an object id, other, or all)
the offset along the x-axis
the offset along the y-axis

Function.Name: physics_fixture_create
Function.Description: This function creates a new physics fixture.

Function.Name: physics_fixture_delete
Function.Description: This function deletes the given fixture, freeing the memory it is using.
Function.Parameter: the fixture that is to be deleted from memory

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_angular_damping
Function.Description: This function sets the angular damping of the given fixture. Normally you will use a damping value between 0 and 1, but you can use any non-negative value if required.
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture
the angular damping of the fixture, usually between 0 and 1

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_awake
Function.Description: This function sets whether the given physics fixture should be "awake" (whether it is processing events and interacting with the surrounding instances).
Function.Parameter: the id of the bound fixture
whether the fixture is awake (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_box_shape
Function.Description: This function defines a box shape for the given fixture. It takes the half width and height as the physics world uses this value far more than whole width/height values to determine things like collisions.
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture
the half width of the box
the half height of the box

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_chain_shape
Function.Description: This function tells the given fixture to use a "chain" shape, which consists of a number of points that are connected using edge shapes. The points are specified after calling this function using physics_fixture_add_point().
Function.Parameter: The index of the fixture
Whether to close the chain (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_circle_shape
Function.Description: This function defines a circle shape for your fixture with a radius defined by the argument "rad".
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture
radius of the circle

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_collision_group
Function.Description: This function assigns a collision group to the given fixture.
Function.Parameter: the fixture that is to be bound
the group that this fixture is assigned to (either a positive value, 0, or a negative value)

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_density
Function.Description: This function sets the density of the given physics fixture.
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture
the density of the fixture calculated as kg/m

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_edge_shape
Function.Description: This function defines an "edge" shape for the give fixture.
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture
start x position for the edge
start y position for the edge
end x position for the edge
end y position for the edge

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_friction
Function.Description: This function sets the friction of the given physics fixture. Note that the friction is usually set to a value between 0 and 1, but you can use any non-negative value if required.
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture
the friction of the fixture

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_kinematic
Function.Description: This function sets the given physics fixture to be kinematic (a kinematic fixture will not be affected by any forces).
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_linear_damping
Function.Description: This function sets the linear damping of the given fixture. Damping parameters should be between 0 and infinity, with 0 meaning no damping, and infinity meaning full damping. Normally you will use a damping value between 0 and 1, but you can use any non-negative value if required.
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture
the damping of the fixture, usually between 0 and 1

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_polygon_shape
Function.Description: This function tells the given fixture to use a polygon shape. The points must be specified after calling this function using physics_fixture_add_point().
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_restitution
Function.Description: This function sets the restitution of the given physics fixture.
Function.Parameter: The index of the fixture
The restitution of the fixture (usually between 0 and 1)

Function.Name: physics_fixture_set_sensor
Function.Description: This function sets whether the given fixture should be a sensor.
Function.Parameter: the index of the fixture
whether a fixture is a sensor (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: physics_get_density
Function.Description: This function returns the density of the given bound fixture.
Function.Parameter: the id of the bound fixture

Function.Name: physics_get_restitution
Function.Description: This function returns the restitution of the given bound fixture.
Function.Parameter: the id of the bound fixture

Function.Name: physics_remove_fixture
Function.Description: This function removes (or "un-binds") a fixture from an instance or instances. This permits you to redefine a new fixture and bind that to the instance. In this way you can change the instance's physical properties without having to destroy and re-create it.
Function.Parameter: The ID of the instance to remove the fixture from
The ID of the fixture that is to be removed from the instance

Function.Name: physics_set_density
Function.Description: This function sets the density value of the given bound fixture.
Function.Parameter: the id of the bound fixture
the new density value to apply

Function.Name: physics_set_friction
Function.Description: This function sets the friction value of the given bound fixture.
Function.Parameter: the id of the bound fixture
the new friction value to apply

Function.Name: physics_set_restitution
Function.Description: This function sets the restitution value of the given bound fixture.
Function.Parameter: the id of the bound fixture
the new restitution value to apply

Function.Name: physics_apply_angular_impulse
Function.Description: This function will give an angular impulse to a physics-enabled instance. This impulse will set the angular rotation by the amount given, ignoring the current torque, essentially setting the amount of "spin" that a fixture has.
Function.Parameter: The impulse (in Newton metres) to be applied

Function.Name: physics_apply_force
Function.Description: This function applies a force to the current physics-enabled instance.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate in the room where the force will be applied
The y coordinate in the room where the force will be applied
The x component of the force vector
The y component of the force vector

Function.Name: physics_apply_impulse
Function.Description: This function applies an impulse to the current physics-enabled instance.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate in the room where the impulse will be applied
The y coordinate in the room where the impulse will be applied
The x component of the impulse vector
The y component of the impulse vector

Function.Name: physics_apply_local_force
Function.Description: This function applies a local force to the current physics-enabled instance.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate relative to the origin where the force will be applied
The y coordinate relative to the origin where the force will be applied
The x component of the force vector
The y component of the force vector

Function.Name: physics_apply_local_impulse
Function.Description: This function applies a local impulse to the current physics-enabled instance.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate relative to the origin where the impulse will be applied
The y coordinate relative to the origin where the impulse will be applied
The x component of the impulse vector (relative to the xpos coordinate)
The y component of the impulse vector (relative to the ypos coordinate)

Function.Name: physics_apply_torque
Function.Description: This function applies a torque to the given physics-enabled instance.
Function.Parameter: The torque (in Newton metres) to be applied

Function.Name: physics_joint_delete
Function.Description: This function deletes the given physics joint.
Function.Parameter: The index of the joint that you wish to delete

Function.Name: physics_joint_distance_create
Function.Description: This function creates a distance joint between two physics instances. A distance joint is one of the simplest joints and says that the distance between two points on two instances must be constant.
Function.Parameter: The first instance to connect with the joint
The second instance to connect with the joint
The first x coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The first y coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The second x coordinate for the joint, within the game world
the second y coordinate for the joint, within the game world
Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: physics_joint_enable_motor
Function.Description: This function sets whether to enable or disable the motor on a physics joint that has a motor.
Function.Parameter: The joint that you wish to enable or disable the motor on
Whether you wish to turn the motor on (true) or off (false)

Function.Name: physics_joint_friction_create
Function.Description: This function creates a friction joint between two physics instances. A friction joint is a bit different to all other joints in the physics simulation in that the connection created will not constrain the instances' position or movement, but rather their speed and rotation.
Function.Parameter: The first instance to connect with the joint
The second instance to connect with the joint
The x coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The y coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The maximum frictional force that will be applied
The maximum rotational force that will be applied
Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: physics_joint_gear_create
Function.Description: This function creates a gear joint between two physics instances.
Function.Parameter: The first instance to connect with the joint
The second instance to connect with the joint
A previously defined revolute joint
A previously defined revolute or prismatic joint
Set the velocity ratio between the two joints

Function.Name: physics_joint_get_value
Function.Description: This function returns the value of the joint property corresponding to the given joint constant.
Function.Parameter: The index of the joint that you wish to test
The constant for the joint property that you wish to test

Function.Name: physics_joint_prismatic_create
Function.Description: This function creates a prismatic joint between two physics instances. Like a revolute joint, the prismatic joint only has one degree of freedom, but with this joint it is directional relative to an axis rather than rotational and actually prevents any form of rotation.
Function.Parameter: The first instance to connect with the joint
The second instance to connect with the joint
The x coordinate where the joint is anchored, within the game world
The y coordinate where the joint is anchored, within the game world
The x component of the axis vector
The y component of the axis vector
The lower permitted limit for the joint movement
The lower permitted limit for the joint movement
Whether to limit the movement of the joint (true) or not (false)
Sets the maximum movement speed for the motor
This is the speed at which the motor should move
Whether the motor should be active (true) or not (false)
Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: physics_joint_pulley_create
Function.Description: This function creates a pulley joint between two physics instances. A pulley joint is used to connect two instances within the physics world in such a way that moving one will directly influence the movement of the other.
Function.Parameter: The first instance to connect with the joint
The second instance to connect with the joint
The x coordinate where the first part of joint is anchored, within the game world
The y coordinate where the first part of the joint is anchored, within the game world
The x coordinate where the second part of the joint is anchored, within the game world
The y coordinate where the second part of the joint is anchored, within the game world
The local x coordinate where joint 1 is anchored to the first instance
The local y coordinate where joint 1 is anchored to the first instance
The local x coordinate where joint 2 is anchored to the second instance
The local y coordinate where joint 2 is anchored to the second instance
Set the velocity ratio between two instances
Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: physics_joint_revolute_create
Function.Description: This function creates a revolute joint between two physics instances. A revolute joint forces two bodies to share a common anchor point (often called a hinge point) and the joint has a single degree of freedom - the relative rotation of the two bodies around this point.
Function.Parameter: The first instance to connect with the joint
The second instance to connect with the joint
The x coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The y coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The lower permitted limit for the joint angle
The upper permitted limit for the joint angle
Whether the to limit the angle of the joint (true) or not (false)
Sets the maximum motor torque used to achieve the desired motor speed (in Newtons per meter)
This is the speed at which the motor should rotate
Whether the motor should be active (true) or not (false)
Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: physics_joint_rope_create
Function.Description: This function creates a rope joint between two physics instances. A rope joint is one which is used to join two instances that you want to keep a constant distance apart, no matter what other forces are acting on it.
Function.Parameter: The first instance to connect with the joint
The second instance to connect with the joint
The first x coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The first y coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The second x coordinate for the joint, within the game world
the second y coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The maximum length that the joint can "stretch"
Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: physics_joint_set_value
Function.Description: This function sets the value of the joint property corresponding to the given joint constant to the given value.
Function.Parameter: The index of the joint that you wish to change
The constant for the joint property that you wish to change
The new value for the joint property

Function.Name: physics_joint_weld_create
Function.Description: This function creates a weld joint between two physics instances. The weld joint is designed to attach two fixtures together in a strong, yet flexible bond and will permit flexing between the two joined fixtures but without the stretching associated with, for example, a distance joint, and will always try to "spring" back to the reference angle when put under any stress or load.
Function.Parameter: The first instance to connect with the joint
The second instance to connect with the joint
The x coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The y coordinate for the joint, within the game world
The joint angle to maintain
This is the oscillation frequency for the joint, in hertz
This damping ratio for the joint
Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: physics_joint_wheel_create
Function.Description: This function creates a wheel joint between two physics instances. A wheel joint combines a piston and a revolute joint, like a wheel mounted on the shock absorber of a car.
Function.Parameter: The first instance to connect with the joint
The second instance to connect with the joint
The x coordinate where the joint is anchored, within the game world
The y coordinate where the joint is anchored, within the game world
The x component of the wheel axis vector
The y component of the wheel axis vector
Whether the motor should be active (true) or not (false)
Sets the maximum motor torque used to achieve the desired motor speed (in Newtons per meter)
This is the speed at which the motor should rotate
This is the oscillation frequency for the joint, in hertz
This damping ratio for the joint
Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

Function.Name: physics_particle_count
Function.Description: This function will return the number of particles that are active in a physics-enabled room.

Function.Name: physics_particle_create
Function.Description: With this function you can create a single particle anywhere within your game room, setting certain flags and properties.
Function.Parameter: The flags to set on the particle.
The x position to create the particle at.
The y position to create the particle at.
The initial horizontal velocity.
The initial vertical velocity.
The base colour to use for the particle.
The base alpha to use for the particle.
The user-defined category to which the particle belongs.

Function.Name: physics_particle_delete
Function.Description: With this function you can delete (remove) a particle from the physics simulation in the current room.
Function.Parameter: The index (ID) of the particle to delete.

Function.Name: physics_particle_delete_region_box
Function.Description: With this function you can delete (remove) all the particles that fall within the bounds of the defined rectangular area from the physics simulation in the current room.
Function.Parameter: The x position of the center of the area to delete.
The y position of the center of the area to delete.
The half width of the rectangle.
The half height of the rectangle.

Function.Name: physics_particle_delete_region_circle
Function.Description: With this function you can delete (remove) all the particles that fall within the bounds of the defined circular area from the physics simulation in the current room.
Function.Parameter: The x position of the center of the area to delete.
The y position of the center of the area to delete.
The radius (in pixels) of the circular area to delete.

Function.Name: physics_particle_delete_region_poly
Function.Description: With this function you can delete (remove) all the particles that fall within the bounds of the defined polygonal area from the physics simulation in the current room.
Function.Parameter: A DS list of points to use to create the polygon.

Function.Name: physics_particle_draw
Function.Description: This function will draw a sprite at the position of all the particles that share the same user-defined category value, and that have flags which coincide with those set for the mask. The mask value is defined in the same way as you would define the flags when creating the particle, i.e.: using the bitwise or "|" to mask off the appropriate bits for each flag.
Function.Parameter: The mask to compare the particles flags with.
The user-defined category to draw (use 0 to draw all categories).
The sprite to use for each particle.
The image_index of the sprite to draw.

Function.Name: physics_particle_draw_ext
Function.Description: This function will draw a sprite at the position of all the particles that share the same user-defined category value, and that have flags which coincide with those set for the mask. The mask value is defined in the same way as you would define the flags when creating the particles, i.e.: using the bitwise or "|" to mask off the appropriate bits for each flag.
Function.Parameter: The mask to compare the particles flags with.
The user-defined category to draw (use 0 to draw all categories).
The sprite to use for each particle.
The image_index of the sprite to draw.
The scale factor to apply to the sprite along the x axis.
The scale factor to apply to the sprite along the y axis.
The angle (in degrees) to draw the sprite at.
The colour to blend with the sprite (default is c_white).
The alpha value to use when drawing (0 - 1).

Function.Name: physics_particle_get_damping
Function.Description: With this function you can find out what the current linear damping is for particles in the physics simulation (you can set this value using physics_particle_set_damping()).

Function.Name: physics_particle_get_data
Function.Description: This function returns various pieces of information about each particle in the physics simulation using the given flags checked. The buffer used must have been created previously using the function buffer_create(), and should be of the "grow" type, with the size being approximately that of the expected return data.
Function.Parameter: The (previously created) buffer to use to store the data.
The flags to use to extract data about specific particle types.

Function.Name: physics_particle_get_data_particle
Function.Description: This function returns various pieces of information about a single particle in the physics simulation using the given flags checked. The particle index (its ID) is that which was returned by the function physics_particle_create(), and the buffer used must have been created previously using the function buffer_create(). The buffer should be of the "grow" type, with the size being approximately that of the expected return data.
Function.Parameter: The index (ID) of the particle to get the data from.
The (previously created) buffer to use to store the data.
The flags to use to extract data about specific particle types.

Function.Name: physics_particle_get_density
Function.Description: With this function you can find out what the current density is for particles in the physics simulation (you can set this value using physics_particle_set_density()).

Function.Name: physics_particle_get_gravity_scale
Function.Description: With this function you can find out what the current gravity scale factor is for particles in the physics simulation (you can set this value using physics_particle_set_gravity_scale()).

Function.Name: physics_particle_get_group_flags
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the group flags for a group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), and the function will return a value which is the combined value of the currently set flags.
Function.Parameter: The particle group to get.

Function.Name: physics_particle_get_max_count
Function.Description: With this function you can find out what the current cap value is on particles permitted in the physics simulation (you can set this value using physics_particle_set_max_count()).

Function.Name: physics_particle_get_radius
Function.Description: With this function you can find out what the current radius (in pixels) is for particles in the physics simulation (you can set this value using physics_particle_set_radius()).

Function.Name: physics_particle_group_add_point
Function.Description: This function sets a point in the room to define the shape of a polygon which will be used to create a group of soft body particles. You must have previously signaled to GameMaker that you are going define a polygon shape using the function physics_particle_group_polygon() and then use this function to define the individual points of the polygon.
Function.Parameter: The x position in the room for the point.
The y position in the room for the point.

Function.Name: physics_particle_group_begin
Function.Description: With this function you can create a group of particles in a room.
Function.Parameter: The flags to set on the particle.
The group flags to set on the particle.
The x position to create the particle group at.
The y position to create the particle group at.
The angle (in degrees) to rotate the group to on create.
The initial horizontal velocity.
The initial vertical velocity.
The initial angular velocity.
The base colour to use for the particle group.
The base alpha to use for the particle group.
Set the cohesion strength between particles in the group.
The user-defined category to which the group belongs.

Function.Name: physics_particle_group_box
Function.Description: This function will set the shape of the particle group that is being created to a box shape.
Function.Parameter: The half width of the box.
The half height of the box.

Function.Name: physics_particle_group_circle
Function.Description: This function will set the shape of the particle group that is being created to a circle shape.
Function.Parameter: The radius (in pixels) of the circle to create.

Function.Name: physics_particle_group_count
